item.title: Contact (1997 film)
item.description:
Contact (1997 film) 🔗

Contact is a 1997 American science fiction drama film directed by Robert Zemeckis, based on Carl Sagan’s 1985 novel of the same name. The film stars Jodie Foster as Dr. Eleanor Arroway, a SETI scientist who discovers evidence of extraterrestrial life and is chosen to make first contact.

Plot 🔗

Dr. Ellie Arroway, driven by the childhood loss of her father and inspired by his encouragement of her amateur radio hobby, dedicates her life to SETI research at the Arecibo Observatory. Facing funding cuts led by President’s science advisor David Drumlin, she secures private funding from the reclusive billionaire S.R. Hadden to continue her work at the Very Large Array (VLA) in New Mexico.

Four years later, Arroway discovers a signal from the star Vega containing a sequence of prime numbers. The discovery leads to a global effort to decode the message, which is complicated by Drumlin and the National Security Council’s attempts to control the facility. The signal is found to contain a video of Adolf Hitler’s opening address at the 1936 Summer Olympics, the first Earth transmission strong enough to reach Vega.

Arroway’s team decodes the signal, revealing schematics for a complex machine designed to transport a single person. Multiple nations collaborate to fund the machine’s construction at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral. An international panel is formed to select a candidate for the journey. Arroway is a leading contender, but her atheism, highlighted by panel member Palmer Joss, jeopardizes her selection. Drumlin is chosen, but a religious terrorist destroys the machine during testing, killing Drumlin and others.

Hadden, now terminally ill and living on the Mir space station, informs Arroway of a second, secretly constructed machine in Hokkaido, Japan. Arroway is selected to use it. Equipped with recording devices, she enters the pod and travels through wormholes, observing alien structures and a celestial event. She finds herself on a beach resembling a childhood drawing of Pensacola, Florida, and encounters an alien taking the form of her deceased father, who explains that the aliens have been monitoring humanity’s radio emissions and have deemed them ready for first contact.

Arroway awakens in the pod, which has only fallen a short distance into a safety net. Mission control insists that the experiment achieved nothing, and her recording devices show only static. A Congressional Committee, led by Michael Kitz, investigates the possibility of a hoax orchestrated by Hadden, who has since died. Arroway asks the committee to accept her testimony on faith, emphasizing the profound impact of her experience. Kitz and Rachel Constantine, a White House official, acknowledge that Arroway’s device recorded 18 hours of static. Arroway receives continued funding for SETI research at the VLA.

Cast 🔗

The film features a cast of notable actors:

  • Jodie Foster as Dr. Eleanor “Ellie” Ann Arroway
  • Jena Malone as young Ellie
  • Matthew McConaughey as Palmer Joss
  • David Morse as Theodore Arroway
  • Tom Skerritt as Dr. David Drumlin
  • James Woods as Michael Kitz
  • John Hurt as S. R. Hadden
  • William Fichtner as Kent Clarke
  • Angela Bassett as Rachel Constantine
  • Jake Busey as Joseph
  • Rob Lowe as Richard Rank
  • Geoffrey Blake as Fisher
  • Max Martini as Willie
  • Steven Ford as Major John Russell
  • Jay Leno as himself
  • Larry King as himself
  • Ann Druyan as herself

Production 🔗

Development 🔗

Carl Sagan conceived Contact in 1979 with Lynda Obst and Peter Guber at Casablanca FilmWorks. Sagan and Ann Druyan completed the film treatment in 1980, aiming to depict a realistic first contact scenario. Kip Thorne consulted on wormhole travel. The character of Ellie Arroway was not directly inspired by Jill Tarter, though Foster met her for research. The name Ellie was inspired by Eleanor Roosevelt.

The project faced numerous rewrites and stalled development. Sagan rewrote Contact as a novel, published in 1985. Roland Joffé and George Miller were initially attached to direct but later departed.

Filming 🔗

Robert Zemeckis took over as director, securing artistic control. Filming began in September 1996 and concluded in February 1997. Key locations included the Very Large Array (VLA) in New Mexico, Warner Hollywood Studios, and Culver Studios. CNN news personalities were scripted into the film to enhance realism. Second unit filming took place at the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico, Fiji, Saint John, US Virgin Islands, and Newfoundland, Canada. Technical consultants from the SETI Institute, Caltech, and a former White House staff member were involved. Sagan participated in the production until his death in December 1996, and the film is dedicated to him.

Visual effects 🔗

Eight VFX companies, including Sony Pictures Imageworks, Weta Digital, and Industrial Light & Magic, collaborated on the visual effects. Weta Digital designed the wormhole sequence. Digital alterations were made to news footage of Bill Clinton. Digital color correction addressed continuity issues during location shooting. The opening scene is a five-minute CGI sequence depicting a zoom out from Earth to the distant universe. The mirror shot was created through three different plates and manipulated in CGI. The machine was designed by concept artist Steve Burg, reusing a design he created as a “time-displacement device” for an unused scene in Terminator 2.

Music 🔗

Alan Silvestri composed and conducted the original score. A soundtrack album was released in August 1997.

Themes 🔗

Contact explores the cultural conflicts between religion and science, particularly concerning the existence of God. The film presents various viewpoints on faith and scientific evidence. It depicts intense public debate about the implications of alien contact, including questions about morality and the role of science. The film raises questions about the authenticity of Arroway’s journey, leaving room for doubt. The film suggests that science and religion can coexist.

Release 🔗

Contact’s release in July 1997 boosted interest in Sagan’s novel. The book appeared on The New York Times Best Seller list. The film premiered on July 1, 1997, and was released in the United States and Canada on July 11, 1997.

Critical reception 🔗

The film received generally positive reviews. Critics praised its exploration of scientific and theological concepts but noted weaknesses in storytelling.

Awards 🔗

Contact won the Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation and two Saturn Awards. It received nominations for an Academy Award for Best Sound and a Golden Globe Award for Best Lead Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama (Jodie Foster).

Reactions 🔗

Bill Clinton 🔗

The film used digitally altered footage of President Bill Clinton, leading to a protest from the White House.

CNN 🔗

CNN chairman Tom Johnson expressed regret over allowing CNN staff to appear in the film, citing concerns about blurring the lines between news and entertainment.

NASA 🔗

The scene involving a cyanide pill caused controversy, with conflicting accounts from NASA advisor Gerald D. Griffin and Carl Sagan.

SETI 🔗

SETI.org published a review of the film, highlighting its accuracy in depicting SETI research.

Lawsuits 🔗

Director George Miller unsuccessfully sued Warner Bros. over breach of contract policies. Francis Ford Coppola sued Warner Bros. and Sagan, claiming that Sagan’s novel was based on a story they had developed together. Coppola’s claim was dismissed.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_(1997_American_film)

item.title: Alienoid (2022 film)
item.description:
Alienoid (2022 film) 🔗

A 2022 South Korean science fiction action film directed by Choi Dong-hoon, starring Ryu Jun-yeol, Kim Woo-bin, and Kim Tae-ri. The film involves time travel between the Goryeo era and the present day, with the appearance of aliens. It was released in IMAX and 4DX formats. A sequel, Alienoid: Return to the Future, was released in 2024.

Plot 🔗

The plot alternates between the modern day and the Goryeo era.

Prologue: 1380 A.D. 🔗

Monk warriors fail to defeat an alien and its human host. Guard and Thunder, humanoid robots from the future, extract the alien. The dying host asks Guard to care for her baby, but Guard initially refuses due to non-interference policies. Thunder smuggles the infant back with them to the modern day.

Timeline 1: 2012-2022 A.D. 🔗

Guard raises the baby girl, Yi-an, without revealing his true identity. Yi-an becomes suspicious and discovers the truth about Guard, Thunder, and her origins.

Yi-an finds her way to Jisan Hospital, the site of an incoming alien prisoner transport. Guard and Thunder explain alien imprisonment mechanics. A prisoner-aligned alien ship arrives, planning to awaken the Controller and release haava to transform Earth’s atmosphere, awakening all alien prisoners and poisoning humanity. The pilot awakens the Controller and releases haava, devastating the city and awakening other prisoners.

Guard, Thunder, and Yi-an kill the alien pilot and prevent further haava release. Badly wounded, Yi-an travels back in time with the aliens, intending to strand them in the past. Guard is destroyed, Thunder sinks in a river, and the Controller is forced to abandon its host.

Timeline 2: 1391 A.D. 🔗

Ten years after Thunder crash-lands, a Taoist bounty hunter named Mureuk pursues the Divine Blade (Guard’s power source). Mureuk meets martial arts figures like the Monk Guru, the Dual Mages, and Dogturd. He also meets Yi-an (the “Girl Who Shoots Thunder”) and Suiter and Ja-jang, aliens from the future who have taken over a local cult. The Divine Blade and Thunder’s location are key to controlling the haava release.

A chaotic battle ensues. Yi-an lures one alien away, while the other is defeated. Yi-an approaches Thunder’s location.

Monk Guru, the Dual Mages, and Dogturd were all near the initial alien crash and are potential hosts for the Controller. However, Mureuk, Monk Guru’s apprentice, rescued Yi-an and became the Controller’s new host, losing his memories.

Cast 🔗

  • Ryu Jun-yeol as Mureuk, a Taoist bounty hunter.
  • Kim Woo-bin as Guard and Thunder, supernatural beings.
  • Kim Tae-ri as Yi-an, a woman who shoots thunder.
  • So Ji-sub as Moon Do-seok, a detective.
  • Yum Jung-ah as Heug-seol, a mage.
  • Jo Woo-jin as Cheong-woon, a mage.
  • Kim Eui-sung as Ja-jang, a masked man.
  • Lee Hanee as Min Gae-in, a curious woman.
  • Shin Jung-geun as Right King, a follower of Mureuk.
  • Lee Si-hoon as Left King, a follower of Mureuk.
  • Ji Kun-woo as Suiter, a man in a modern suit.
  • Kim Dae-myung as the voice of Thunder.
  • Shim Dal-gi as a bride replaced by Yi-an.
  • Yoon Byung-hee as a shaman.
  • Kim Ki-cheon as Dogturd, a man who knows the location of the divine sword.
  • Yoon Kyung-ho as a patient at Jisan Hospital.
  • Ok Ja-yeon as a doctor at Jisan Hospital.
  • Lee Seon-hee as an inn owner.
  • Yoo Jae-myung as Hyun-gam.
  • Kim Hae-sook as an old woman in Goryeo.
  • Jeon Yeo-been as Hong Eon-nyeon, a woman with an alien prisoner.

Production 🔗

Filming took place over 13 months, with both parts filmed simultaneously. Choi Dong-hoon spent two and a half years writing the script. Jang Young-gyu and Kim Tae-kyung were in charge of music and cinematography, respectively. Yoo Sang-seop and Ryu Seong-cheol served as martial arts directors. Ryu Seong-hee and Lee Ha-jun were the art directors. Dexter Studio handled the CG. Filming locations included Andong, North Gyeongsang Province. The production cost for both parts was estimated at 40 billion won.

Release 🔗

Alienoid was released on July 20, 2022, in South Korea in IMAX and 4DX formats by CJ E&M. Well Go USA acquired North American distribution rights. It was the closing film at the 21st New York Asian Film Festival and screened at the 26th Fantasia International Film Festival. It became available for streaming on Netflix from December 28, 2022.

Reception 🔗

The film received mixed reviews from South Korean critics, with some praising its unique worldview and others criticizing its confusing characters and lore. It was compared to Choi Dong-hoon’s previous film, Jeon Woo-chi: The Taoist Wizard. The film was a box-office failure, requiring 7 million admissions to break even.

Sequel 🔗

Alienoid: Return to the Future was released in January 2024.

Accolades 🔗

The film received nominations for several awards, including:

  • Baeksang Arts Awards: Yum Jung-ah nominated for Best Supporting Actress – Film
  • Blue Dragon Film Awards: Nominated for Technical Award
  • Buil Film Awards: Yum Jung-ah nominated for Best Supporting Actress, also nominated for Best Music
  • Chunsa Film Art Awards: Nominated for Technical Award (VFX)
  • Director’s Cut Awards: Choi Dong-hoon nominated for Best Director in film
  • Grand Bell Awards: Won Best Art Direction and Best Visual Effects, also nominated for Best Film Editing, Best Costume Design, and Best Music

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alienoid

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens 🔗

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and large, black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the image of Grey aliens.

Description 🔗

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoids with grey skin, elongated bodies, small chests, and a lack of muscular definition. They are said to lack external human body parts like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their most striking feature is their disproportionately large heads with no hair and large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance 🔗

This subsection further elaborates on the physical appearance of Grey aliens. They are generally depicted as lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. The most prominent feature is their large, black, almond-shaped eyes, often described as lacking eye whites. They are also frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli 🔗

This subsection explains the origin of the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association began with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and determined that the aliens’ home was Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History 🔗

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype. It notes that descriptions of beings similar to Greys predate alien encounter claims, citing H.G. Wells’ descriptions of future humans in “The Man of the Year Million” (1893) and the Eloi in “The Time Machine” (1895).

Origins 🔗

This subsection explores the literary and occult origins of the Grey alien concept. H.G. Wells’ depictions of future humans and the Eloi are mentioned as early examples of beings with Grey-like characteristics. Aleister Crowley’s 1917 encounter with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, described as similar to a modern Grey, is also discussed. Gustav Sandgren’s 1933 science fiction novel, Den okända faran (The Unknown Danger), which describes a race of extraterrestrials with grey skin, bald heads, and large eyes, is identified as a key influence on the modern image of Grey aliens.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction 🔗

This subsection focuses on the Barney and Betty Hill abduction case and its role in popularizing the Grey alien archetype. The Hills claimed that in 1961, they were abducted by grayish-skinned humanoid beings and taken aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer’s 1990 article suggests that Barney’s memories, revealed under hypnosis, may have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which featured an alien with large eyes. Carl Sagan echoed these suspicions, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore 🔗

This subsection discusses how Grey aliens became an integral part of ufology and extraterrestrial-related folklore after the Hill’s encounter. Journalist C.D.B. Bryan notes that 73% of reported alien encounters in the United States describe Grey aliens. The section also mentions the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, and claims that individuals saw the U.S. military handling child-sized beings with oversized heads and slanted eyes. Whitley Strieber’s 1987 book Communion, which described his alleged encounters with Greys, is also discussed. Jimmy Guieu’s 1988 interview on TF1’s Ciel, mon mardi! introduced the term “the little greys” to the French public.

The section further notes that Greys have become the subject of many conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of a government disinformation campaign or a product of mind-control experiments. Ray Santilli’s 1995 film Alien Autopsy, which claimed to depict the autopsy of a “real” Grey, is also mentioned.

Analysis 🔗

This section examines various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology 🔗

This subsection analyzes the role of Greys in alien abduction claims. It notes that Greys make up a significant percentage of reported alien encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focus of abduction claims, with abductees reporting that the Greys stare into their eyes during mental procedures.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence 🔗

This subsection presents neurologist Steven Novella’s theory that Grey aliens are a byproduct of the human imagination, with their distinctive features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” 🔗

This subsection discusses Frederick V. Malmstrom’s “Mother Hypothesis,” which suggests that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development. Malmstrom argues that the face of a Grey can be reconstructed through transformation of a mother’s face based on early-childhood sensation and perception.

Evolutionary implausibility 🔗

This subsection presents biologist Jack Cohen’s argument that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses 🔗

This subsection briefly mentions alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of alleged Grey aliens, including the interdimensional hypothesis, the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, and the time-traveler hypothesis.

In popular culture 🔗

This section explores the depiction of Grey aliens in popular culture. It notes that Greys have become a common way to depict extraterrestrials in fiction, supplanting the “little green men” archetype. Examples include Ultraman (1966), Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Babylon 5, Stargate, and South Park. The section also mentions the increasing association of Greys with conspiracy theories in the 1990s, citing The X-Files as a prominent example. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The films Paul (2011) and Dark Skies (2013) are also mentioned, as well as the TV series Resident Alien (2021) and the game Greyhill Incident (2023).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_aliens

Description 🔗

Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition, and having disproportionately short legs. A key feature is their large heads relative to their bodies, devoid of hair, with small orifices for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their eyes are large, opaque, black, and almond-shaped. History 🔗

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype.

Origins 🔗

Descriptions of beings resembling Grey aliens predate reported encounters. H.G. Wells described future humans with similar features in his 1893 article “The Man of the Year Million” and his 1895 novel The Time Machine. In 1917, Aleister Crowley described an entity named Lam with a similar appearance. In 1933, Swedish novelist Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, described aliens with grey clothes, bald heads, and large eyes in his science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction 🔗

Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage of an autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from Roswell, but later admitted it was a “reconstruction.”

Analysis 🔗

This section explores various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology 🔗

Greys are frequently associated with alien abduction claims, accounting for a significant percentage of reported encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focal point, with claims of inducing hallucinogenic states or emotions through staring.

Neurologist Steven Novella suggests that Grey aliens are a product of the human imagination, with their features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” 🔗

Frederick V. Malmstrom proposes that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development, reconstructing the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face.

Biologist Jack Cohen argues that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses 🔗

The interdimensional, cryptoterrestrial, and time-traveler hypotheses offer alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of these alleged beings.

In popular culture 🔗

This section highlights the presence of Grey aliens in various forms of media.

Grey aliens have become a common depiction of extraterrestrials in fiction, replacing the earlier “little green men.” They have appeared in films and television shows such as Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, and Stargate. During the 1990s, plotlines linking Greys to conspiracy theories became prevalent, as seen in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The film Paul features a Grey alien who attributes the Greys’ presence in pop culture to government manipulation. The film Dark Skies features child abduction by Greys. Greys also appear in the TV series Resident Alien and the game Greyhill Incident.

item.title: Alien (film)
item.description:
Alien (film) 🔗

Alien is a 1979 science fiction horror film directed by Ridley Scott and written by Dan O’Bannon. The film follows the crew of the commercial spaceship Nostromo as they encounter a deadly extraterrestrial creature. The film stars Tom Skerritt, Sigourney Weaver, Veronica Cartwright, Harry Dean Stanton, John Hurt, Ian Holm, and Yaphet Kotto.

Plot 🔗

The commercial spaceship Nostromo is returning to Earth when its computer detects a transmission from a nearby planetoid. The crew investigates a derelict alien spaceship and discovers a chamber containing hundreds of eggs. One of the crew members, Kane, is attacked by a creature that attaches itself to his face. The creature eventually detaches itself, and Kane appears to be fine. However, during a meal, a small alien creature bursts from his chest, killing him. The crew then tries to hunt down and kill the alien, which grows into a deadly creature. The crew members are killed off one by one, until only Ripley remains. She initiates the ship’s self-destruct sequence and escapes in a shuttle, but the alien stows away. Ripley manages to blast the alien into space before putting herself into stasis for the return to Earth.

Cast 🔗

  • Tom Skerritt as Dallas, captain of the Nostromo.
  • Sigourney Weaver as Ripley, the warrant officer.
  • Veronica Cartwright as Lambert, the navigator.
  • Harry Dean Stanton as Brett, the engineering technician.
  • John Hurt as Kane, the executive officer.
  • Ian Holm as Ash, the science officer who is revealed to be an android.
  • Yaphet Kotto as Parker, the chief engineer.
  • Bolaji Badejo as the alien.
  • Helen Horton as the voice of Mother, the Nostromo’s computer.

Production 🔗

Writing 🔗

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the screenplay, with O’Bannon initially writing 29 pages titled Memory. The story was influenced by various science fiction and horror works, including The Thing from Another World, Forbidden Planet, and Planet of the Vampires. The script was pitched as “Jaws in space”. Hill and Giler made revisions to the script, adding the android character Ash.

Development 🔗

20th Century-Fox greenlit Alien after the success of Star Wars. Ridley Scott was chosen as the director. Scott created detailed storyboards, which led to the film’s budget being doubled.

Casting 🔗

Casting calls were held in New York City and London. Scott wanted strong actors to focus on the film’s visual style. The crew of the Nostromo was intended to resemble working astronauts, described as “truckers in space”. Scott wrote backstories for each character.

Filming 🔗

Filming took place at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios near London, and model filming was done at Bray Studios. The production schedule was short due to the film’s low budget. Sets were constructed for the alien planetoid, the Nostromo, and the derelict spacecraft. The space suits were thick and bulky, causing discomfort for the actors.

Post-production 🔗

Editing and post-production took roughly 20 weeks. The film was edited to have a slow pace to build suspense. One scene that was cut involved Ripley encountering Dallas and Brett, who had been partially cocooned by the alien.

Music 🔗

Jerry Goldsmith composed the musical score. Scott initially wanted Isao Tomita, but Fox wanted a more familiar composer. Goldsmith’s score was nominated for a Golden Globe Award and a Grammy Award, and it won a BAFTA Award.

Design 🔗

Creature effects 🔗

H. R. Giger designed the alien and its environment. The “facehugger” was the first creature Giger designed. The “chestburster” design was inspired by Francis Bacon’s painting Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion.

The alien 🔗

Giger made conceptual paintings of the adult alien before settling on the final version. Carlo Rambaldi manufactured the head. Bolaji Badejo portrayed the alien in most scenes. Scott chose not to show the full alien for most of the film to create a sense of terror.

Sets 🔗

The sets of the Nostromo’s three decks were created in one piece. Ron Cobb created industrial-style symbols and color-coded signs. The company that owns the Nostromo is referred to as “Weylan-Yutani”. Art director Roger Christian used scrap metal and parts to create set pieces and props.

Spaceships and planets 🔗

Ron Cobb and Chris Foss worked on designs for the spaceship and space suits. Cobb created sketches of the ship’s interiors and exteriors. The spaceships and planets were shot using models and miniatures.

Title sequence 🔗

The title sequence was developed by R/Greenberg Associates.

Release 🔗

Alien was rated “R” in the United States and “X” in the United Kingdom. It opened in a limited release in American theaters on May 25, 1979, and received a wide release on June 22.

Box office 🔗

The film was a commercial success, grossing $78.9 million in the United States and £7,886,000 in the United Kingdom during its first run. Its total worldwide gross has been estimated at between $104.9 million and $203.6 million.

Critical reception 🔗

Critical reaction to Alien was initially mixed. However, in subsequent years, it was critically reassessed and is now considered one of the greatest science fiction and horror films of all time.

Accolades 🔗

Alien won the Academy Award for Best Visual Effects and Saturn Awards for Best Science Fiction Film, Best Direction for Ridley Scott, and Best Supporting Actress for Veronica Cartwright.

Post-release 🔗

Home video 🔗

Alien has been released in many home video formats over the years, including VHS, LaserDisc, and DVD.

Director’s Cut 🔗

In 2003, 20th Century Fox released a “Director’s Cut” of Alien, which included restored footage and recut scenes.

Cinematic analysis 🔗

Critics have analyzed Alien’s sexual overtones and its use of abjection. The film has been interpreted as a metaphor for male fear of penetration and as a representation of the “monstrous-feminine”.

Audience research 🔗

Findings from an international audience research project were published in 2016 as Alien Audiences: Remembering and Evaluating a Classic Movie.

Re-release 🔗

For its 45th anniversary, Alien was re-released in theaters on April 26, 2024.

Legacy 🔗

Critical reassessment 🔗

Despite initial mixed reviews, Alien has received critical acclaim over the years and is seen as one of the most influential science-fiction films.

Cultural influences 🔗

Alien had both an immediate and long-term impact on the science fiction and horror genres. The “chestburster” effect was parodied in Mel Brooks’s comedy Spaceballs. Nintendo’s Metroid video game series was significantly influenced by Alien.

Merchandise 🔗

Alan Dean Foster wrote a novelization of the film. Heavy Metal magazine published a graphic novel adaptation. Model kits and action figures of the alien were released.

School play adaptation 🔗

In 2019, students at North Bergen High School adapted the film into a play, which gained social media recognition and praise from Ridley Scott and Sigourney Weaver.

Video game adaptation 🔗

Two downloadable content packs for the video game Alien: Isolation depict alternate versions of key events from the film, with the original cast members reprising their roles.

Sequels and franchise 🔗

The success of Alien led to three direct sequels: Aliens (1986), Alien 3 (1992), and Alien Resurrection (1997). The story of Ripley’s encounters with the aliens became the thematic and narrative core of the series. The film series resulted in a media franchise with novels, comic books, video games, and merchandise. A prequel series was started with Prometheus (2012) and continued with Alien: Covenant (2017).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_(film)

item.title: Alien vs. Predator (2004 film)
item.description:
Alien vs. Predator (2004 film) 🔗

A 2004 science fiction action horror film directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, Alien vs. Predator brings together the titular creatures from the Alien and Predator franchises. The story draws inspiration from a 1989 comic book and incorporates elements of Aztec mythology and the writings of Erich von Däniken.

Plot 🔗

In Antarctica, a Predator ship melts a hole in the ice, revealing a buried pyramid. Charles Weyland assembles a team to investigate. The team discovers evidence of an ancient civilization and a sacrificial chamber. Three Predators arrive and descend into the pyramid, where they encounter the humans and awakened Xenomorphs. Battles ensue, and Lex Woods and Sebastian De Rosa learn about the Predators’ history on Earth through hieroglyphs. They discover that the Predators have been visiting Earth for millennia, teaching humans to build pyramids and using them for rite of passage rituals involving Xenomorphs. Lex and Sebastian ally with a Predator named Scar to prevent the Xenomorphs from escaping. Scar destroys the pyramid, but the Xenomorph Queen attacks. Lex and Scar defeat the Queen, and an elder Predator gifts Lex a spear. A Predalien chestburster erupts from Scar’s body on the Predator spaceship.

Cast 🔗

Sanaa Lathan stars as Alexa “Lex” Woods, an experienced guide. Raoul Bova plays Professor Sebastian De Rosa, an Italian archaeologist. Lance Henriksen portrays Charles Bishop Weyland, the head of Weyland Corporation. Ewen Bremner is Dr. Graeme Miller, the main scientist. Colin Salmon plays Maxwell Stafford, Weyland’s assistant. Tommy Flanagan is Mark Verheiden, a member of the armed escort. Tom Woodruff Jr. plays the Alien/Grid, and Ian Whyte plays the Predator/Scar and other Predators.

Production 🔗

Fifth Alien film and sequel 🔗

James Cameron had been working on a fifth Alien film, and Ridley Scott had a concept to explore the origins of the alien creatures. However, upon learning of Alien vs. Predator, Cameron ceased work, believing it would damage the franchise. Ridley Scott also expressed disinterest in the Alien vs. Predator films.

Development 🔗

The concept originated from the Aliens versus Predator comic book. Screenwriter Peter Briggs created a spec screenplay in 1990–1991. The project was delayed due to Alien Resurrection. Paul W. S. Anderson pitched John Davis a story adapting the Machiko Noguchi series. Anderson began working on the film after completing the script for Resident Evil: Apocalypse, with Shane Salerno co-writing.

Story and setting 🔗

Influenced by Erich von Däniken and Aztec mythology, Anderson depicted Predators teaching humans to build pyramids and being treated as gods. The Predators would use Earth for rite of passage rituals every 100 years, hunting Aliens. If overwhelmed, the Predators would use self-destruct weapons. H. P. Lovecraft’s At the Mountains of Madness and the Aliens vs. Predator comic series influenced the story. The film is set on Bouvet Island in Antarctica.

Casting 🔗

Lance Henriksen was the first actor cast, maintaining continuity with the Alien series. He plays Charles Bishop Weyland, tying into the Weyland-Yutani Corporation. Sanaa Lathan was cast as Alexa Woods. Arnold Schwarzenegger was considered for a cameo as Major Alan “Dutch” Schaeffer from Predator. Sigourney Weaver declined to participate.

Filming and set designs 🔗

Production began in 2003 at Barrandov Studios in Prague. Richard Bridgland designed sets, props, and vehicles. 25 to 30 life-sized sets were constructed, including interiors of the pyramid. The pyramid’s designs were influenced by Egyptian, Cambodian, and Aztec civilizations. Miniatures were used to enhance realism.

Visual effects and creatures 🔗

Amalgamated Dynamics, Inc. (ADI) designed costumes, miniatures, and effects. The Predators’ wrist blades were extended, and a larger mechanical plasma caster was created. Each Predator was given a unique mask. A hydraulic Alien puppet was created for faster movements. CGI use was minimized. The Alien queen was filmed using practical, puppet, and computer-generated versions.

Music 🔗

Harald Kloser composed the film’s score, recorded in London. The score album was released on iTunes and CD, receiving mixed reviews.

Release 🔗

Home media 🔗

Alien vs. Predator was released on VHS, DVD, and PSP UMD Movies. The DVD included audio commentaries, a “Making of” featurette, and deleted scenes. An “Extreme Edition” and an “Unrated Edition” were also released.

Reception 🔗

Box office 🔗

Alien vs. Predator grossed $177.4 million worldwide.

Critical response 🔗

The film received generally negative reviews. Rotten Tomatoes reported 21% positive reviews, with the consensus being “Gore without scares and cardboard cut-out characters make this clash of the monsters a dull sit.” Metacritic gave the film a score of 29 out of 100, indicating “generally unfavorable” reviews.

Other media 🔗

Sequel 🔗

Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem was released in December 2007.

Related film 🔗

The Predator (2018) featured Lex Wood’s Xenomorph-bone spear.

Related video games 🔗

Several video games were released, including Alien vs. Predator (mobile) and Aliens vs. Pinball.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_vs._Predator_(film)

item.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
item.description:
Close Encounters of the Third Kind 🔗

A 1977 American science fiction drama film directed and written by Steven Spielberg. It tells the story of Roy Neary, an everyday blue-collar worker in Indiana, and Jillian, a single mother, whose lives are changed after encounters with unidentified flying objects.

Plot 🔗

In 1977, French scientist Claude Lacombe and his team examine Flight 19, found abandoned in the Sonoran Desert, and the SS Cotopaxi, found in the Gobi Desert. Near Indianapolis, Roy Neary has a close encounter with a UFO, becoming obsessed with a mountain shape. Jillian Guiler’s son, Barry, is abducted by a UFO. Lacombe’s team investigates increasing UFO activity, discovering a five-tone musical phrase. The coordinates point to Devils Tower in Wyoming. Roy and Jillian, along with others experiencing visions, head to Devils Tower, which is being evacuated by the US Army. They reach the site as UFOs appear. Scientists communicate with the UFOs using light and sound. A mothership arrives, releasing humans and animals, including Barry. Roy is chosen to join the extraterrestrials, entering the mothership as it departs.

Cast 🔗

Richard Dreyfuss stars as Roy Neary, an electrical lineman. François Truffaut plays Claude Lacombe, a French scientist. Teri Garr is Ronnie Neary, Roy’s wife, and Melinda Dillon portrays Jillian Guiler. Cary Guffey plays Barry Guiler, Jillian’s son. Bob Balaban appears as David Laughlin, Lacombe’s assistant.

Production 🔗

Development 🔗

The film’s inspiration came from Steven Spielberg’s childhood experience watching a meteor shower. He developed a deal with Columbia Pictures in 1973. J. Allen Hynek, a UFO consultant, was hired. NASA declined to cooperate.

Filming 🔗

Principal photography began in May 1976. Filming locations included Burbank, California; Devils Tower National Monument in Wyoming; airship hangars in Mobile, Alabama; and a railroad depot in Bay Minette, Alabama. The Sonora Desert sequence was filmed at the Dumont Dunes, California, and the Dharmsala-India exteriors were filmed near Mumbai, India. Technical and budgetary problems arose during filming.

Visual effects 🔗

Douglas Trumbull served as the visual effects supervisor, and Carlo Rambaldi designed the extraterrestrials. The mothership was designed by Ralph McQuarrie and built by Greg Jein. The look of the ship was inspired by an oil refinery Spielberg saw at night in India.

Post-production 🔗

Michael Kahn was the film editor. Pick-ups were commissioned, with John A. Alonzo, László Kovács, and Douglas Slocombe working on them.

Music 🔗

John Williams composed the film score, including the iconic five-tone motif. Spielberg called Williams’s work “When You Wish Upon a Star meets science fiction.” Phillip Dodds from ARP Instruments installed the synthesizer on set and was cast as Jean Claude.

Themes 🔗

The film explores themes of humanity’s readiness to join the cosmos, the impact of new technologies, and spiritual yearning. Judeo-Christian analogies are present, with Devils Tower paralleling Mount Sinai. Communication and tolerance are also highlighted.

Release and reception 🔗

Box office 🔗

The film premiered in New York City on November 16, 1977, and was released nationally in December. It became a box office success, grossing over $300 million worldwide.

Critical reception 🔗

Reviews were mostly positive, with praise for Spielberg’s vision and the film’s climax. Some critics noted a lack of warmth compared to Star Wars.

Reissues and home media 🔗

Several versions of the film have been released, including the original theatrical version, the Special Edition (1980), and the Director’s Cut (1998). The Special Edition added scenes, including the interior of the mothership, while the Director’s Cut removed the mothership interior.

Accolades 🔗

The film received numerous awards and nominations, including Academy Awards, British Academy Film Awards, and Golden Globe Awards. It was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry in 2007.

Legacy 🔗

Close Encounters is credited with launching the reemergence of science fiction films in the 1980s. Spielberg donated to the Planetary Society for extraterrestrial research.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_Encounters_of_the_Third_Kind

item.title: Interdimensional UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Interdimensional UFO Hypothesis 🔗

The interdimensional UFO hypothesis (IUH) proposes that unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings result from encounters with other “dimensions” existing alongside our own. Ufologists such as Meade Layne, John Keel, J. Allen Hynek, and Jacques Vallée have advanced this hypothesis. Proponents suggest that UFOs are a modern manifestation of phenomena throughout human history, previously attributed to mythological or supernatural beings.

History 🔗

Concepts similar to “other dimensions” exist in various religious and mystical traditions.

Pre-modern history 🔗

Islamic mysticism, specifically Sufism, includes the concept of al-ghayb, referring to the hidden and unseen. Within this tradition, ‘ālam al-mithāl, or “the world of similitude,” is an intermediary realm between the physical and spiritual worlds, inhabited by intelligent non-human entities like jinn and angels. Helena Blavatsky, founder of Theosophy, also contributed to the concept of other dimensions.

Theorists 🔗

Background 🔗

In the 19th century, spiritualists believed in “other dimensions.” H.P. Blavatsky popularized the term “planes,” proposing a cosmology of seven planes. The term “ether” was adopted from ancient Greek via Victorian physics and incorporated into occult writings. Charles Webster Leadbeater and Annie Besant introduced the “etheric plane” and “etheric body” in Theosophy. The first use of the word, as inter-dimensional, is in a novel by Z Gale of 1906.

Meade Layne and ‘Ether Ships’ 🔗

On July 4, 1947, occultist Meade Layne claimed that flying discs were “etheric.” Layne, claiming telepathic communication with “people in the saucers,” argued that objects could materialize from an etheric state. He believed these visitors were human beings from another world with good intentions. Layne is regarded as the earliest proponent of the interdimensional hypothesis.

John Keel and ‘Ultraterrestrials’ 🔗

John Keel coined the term “ultraterrestrials” to describe UFO occupants as non-human entities existing in undetectable energy wavelengths. In his 1970 book UFOs: Operation Trojan Horse, Keel argued that a non-human intelligence has staged events to propagate erroneous belief systems, including monsters, ghosts, demons, fairies, vampires, mystery airships, mystery aeroplanes, mystery helicopters, anomalous creature sightings, poltergeist phenomena, balls of light, and UFOs.

Hynek and Vallée 🔗

J. Allen Hynek, an astronomer and scientific advisor to the U.S. Air Force UFO studies (Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book), pioneered the “Close Encounter” classification system. Jacques Vallée, a student of Hynek’s, served as the inspiration for the French researcher portrayed by François Truffaut in the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind. In their 1975 book The Edge of Reality, Vallée and Hynek considered the possibility of “interlocking universes.” Vallée’s 1969 book Passport to Magonia argues for a “parallel universe co-existing with our own.” Vallée’s 1990 paper “Five Arguments Against the Extraterrestrial Origin of Unidentified Flying Objects” summarizes his objections to the extraterrestrial hypothesis.

In popular culture 🔗

The 2008 film Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull utilizes the interdimensional hypothesis, describing ancient aliens traveling into “the space between the spaces.” The 2014 movie Interstellar employs a mix of the interdimensional and time-traveler hypotheses, with future humans evolving to exist in five dimensions and building a tesseract inside a black hole.

Other contrasting hypothesis 🔗

The IUH contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (UFOs are from outside Earth) and the psychosocial hypothesis (UFOs are psychological or social phenomena). Other contrasting hypotheses include:

  • Cryptoterrestrial hypothesis
  • Space animal hypothesis
  • Time-traveler hypothesis

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interdimensional_UFO_hypothesis

item.description:
Interdimensional UFO Hypothesis 🔗

The interdimensional UFO hypothesis (IUH) proposes that unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings result from encounters with other “dimensions” that coexist alongside our own. This idea is supported by ufologists who suggest that UFOs are a modern manifestation of phenomena throughout human history, previously attributed to mythological or supernatural beings.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical context of the interdimensional UFO hypothesis, tracing its roots from pre-modern concepts to modern ufology.

Pre-modern history 🔗

Concepts similar to “other dimensions” exist in various religious and mystical traditions. Islamic mysticism, known as Sufism, includes the concept of al-ghayb, referring to the hidden and unseen. Within this tradition, ‘ālam al-mithāl, or “the world of similitude,” is considered an intermediary realm between the physical and spiritual worlds, inhabited by intelligent non-human entities such as jinn and angels.

Theorists 🔗

This section introduces key figures who have advanced the interdimensional UFO hypothesis.

Background 🔗

In the 19th century, spiritualists believed in “other dimensions.” H.P. Blavatsky popularized the term “planes,” proposing a cosmology of seven planes. The term “ether” was adopted from ancient Greek and incorporated into occult writings. Charles Webster Leadbeater and Annie Besant introduced the “etheric plane” and “etheric body” in Theosophy. The first use of the word, as inter-dimensional, is in a novel by Z Gale of 1906.

Meade Layne and ‘Ether Ships’ 🔗

Meade Layne, an occultist, claimed in 1947 that flying discs were “etheric.” Layne claimed telepathic communication with “people in the saucers,” arguing that objects could pass from an etheric to a dense level of matter. He stated that these visitors were human beings living in their own world with good intentions. Layne is regarded as the earliest proponent of the interdimensional hypothesis.

John Keel and ‘Ultraterrestrials’ 🔗

John Keel coined the term “ultraterrestrials” to describe UFO occupants as non-human entities existing in a wavelength of energy undetectable to us. In his book UFOs: Operation Trojan Horse, Keel argued that a non-human intelligence has staged events to propagate erroneous belief systems, including monsters, ghosts, demons, fairies, vampires, mystery airships, anomalous creatures, poltergeists, and UFOs.

Hynek and Vallée 🔗

J. Allen Hynek, an astronomer and scientific advisor to the U.S. Air Force UFO studies, pioneered the “Close Encounter” classification system. Jacques Vallée, a student of Hynek, served as the inspiration for a character in the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind. In The Edge of Reality, Vallée and Hynek considered the possibility of “interlocking universes.” Vallée argued for a “parallel universe co-existing with our own” in his book Passport to Magonia. Vallée’s 1990 paper “Five Arguments Against the Extraterrestrial Origin of Unidentified Flying Objects” summarized his objections to the extraterrestrial hypothesis.

In popular culture 🔗

This section explores the presence of the interdimensional UFO hypothesis in popular culture.

The 2008 film Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull utilizes the interdimensional hypothesis, describing ancient aliens traveling into “the space between the spaces.” The 2014 movie Interstellar employs a mix of the interdimensional and time-traveler hypotheses, with future humans evolving to exist in five dimensions.

Other contrasting hypothesis 🔗

This section contrasts the IUH with other hypotheses.

The IUH contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis, which suggests UFO sightings are caused by visitations from outside Earth, and the psychosocial hypothesis, which argues UFO sightings are best explained as psychological or social phenomena. Other contrasting hypotheses include the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, space animal hypothesis, and time-traveler hypothesis.

This section lists related topics.

  • Spiritualism

item.title: Aliens Stole My Body (film)
item.description:
Aliens Stole My Body (film) 🔗

This entry focuses on the 2020 American adventure science fiction comedy film Aliens Stole My Body, directed by Sean McNamara. It is based on the novel of the same name by Bruce Coville and serves as a sequel to the 2018 film Aliens Ate My Homework. The film features a cast including Jayden Greig, George Takei, and Dan Payne. It premiered on Netflix on August 4, 2020, in the United States.

Plot 🔗

The crew of the Ferkel returns to Earth to enlist Rod Allbright and Elspeth McMasters to stop BKR, who has escaped from prison. Rod’s friend Mickey joins them as they travel to Mentat to rescue Rod’s father. BKR needs Rod’s father’s knowledge to trap the entire galaxy in a single moment in time. The Allbright family confronts BKR near a black hole.

Cast 🔗

The film stars Jayden Greig as Rod Allbright, George Takei as the voice of Phil the Plant, and Dan Payne as Grakker. Other cast members include Tristan Risk as Madame Pong, Alex Zahara as Tar Gibbons, Lauren McNamara as Elspeth McMasters, Sean Quan as Mickey, Ty Consiglio as Billy Becker, Sandy Robson as Art Allbright, Kirsten Robeck as Gwen Allbright, Christian Convery as Eric Allbright, Carmela Guizzo as Linda Allbright, and Travis Turner as Lackey. Bruce Coville makes a cameo appearance.

Differences from the book 🔗

The film combines plot elements from The Search for Snout and Aliens Stole My Body, the third and fourth books in the Rod Allbright Alien Adventures series, while also introducing original elements.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliens_Stole_My_Body_(film)

item.title: Aliens Ate My Homework (2018 film)
item.description:
Aliens Ate My Homework (2018 film) 🔗

A 2018 American science fiction comedy film directed by Sean McNamara, based on the novel of the same name by Bruce Coville. The film features an ensemble cast including Jayden Greig, William Shatner, Dan Payne, and Alex Zahara. It premiered on Netflix on March 6, 2018, and was followed by a sequel, Aliens Stole My Body (2020).

Plot 🔗

Rod and his cousin Elspeth encounter a group of extraterrestrial lawmen, the Galactic Patrol, after a spaceship crashes through his window and lands on his homework. They must assist the aliens in stopping the plans of the interplanetary criminal BKR, who is disguised on Earth as Billy Becker, a school bully who torments Rod.

Cast 🔗

  • Jayden Greig as Rod Allbright
  • William Shatner as the voice of Phil the Plant
  • Dan Payne as Grakker
  • Tristan Risk as Madame Pong
  • Alex Zahara as Tar Gibbons
  • Lauren McNamara as Elspeth McMasters
  • Ty Consiglio as Billy Becker
  • Kirsten Robek as Gwen Allbright
  • Christian Convery as Eric Allbright
  • Carmela Guizzo as Linda Allbright
  • Christine Lee as Ms. Maloney
  • Sean Quan as Mickey
  • Sandy Robson as Art Allbright
  • Brad Proctor as Phil the Plant puppeteer
  • Jamie Swettenham as Plink puppeteer

Bruce Coville, the author of the original novel, appears as J. Carter, the principal of Rod’s school, “Coville Elementary.” He has a non-speaking role until a mid-credits scene where he reads his own book and narrates the fate of the villain, BKR.

Release 🔗

Universal Pictures Home Entertainment acquired distribution rights to the film in March 2018, releasing it on March 6, 2018. The film’s estimated domestic DVD sales reached $46,603.

References 🔗

A list of sources cited in the article, including news articles and database entries, providing verification for the information presented.

item.title: Uncontacted peoples
item.description:
Uncontacted Peoples 🔗

Uncontacted peoples are Indigenous groups who live without sustained contact with neighboring communities and the world community. They choose to remain isolated, and are referred to as indigenous peoples in voluntary isolation. Estimates suggest there are between 100 and 200 uncontacted tribes, totaling up to 10,000 individuals, primarily located in South America, especially northern Brazil. Knowledge about these groups is mainly gathered from neighboring Indigenous communities and aerial footage.

Definition 🔗

The term “uncontacted peoples” refers to Indigenous groups who have remained largely isolated, maintaining their traditional lifestyles independently from political or governmental entities. While most Indigenous groups have had some form of contact due to European exploration and colonization, “uncontacted” signifies a lack of sustained contact with the majority of non-Indigenous society today. The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights calls them “Indigenous peoples in voluntary isolation,” defined by their rejection of contact with outsiders, including those who previously had contact but chose to return to isolation. These groups are viewed as contemporaries of modernity, not relics of the past. A 2009 United Nations report also includes “peoples in initial contact” who are beginning to integrate into mainstream society. International organizations emphasize their agency by calling them “Indigenous peoples in isolation” or “in voluntary isolation,” also known as “hidden peoples” or “uncontacted tribes.” Historically, European colonial ideas about uncontacted peoples were influenced by the search for Prester John and the Ten Lost Tribes of Israel, identifying them as “lost tribes.”

Relations with Outsiders 🔗

International organizations emphasize protecting indigenous peoples’ lands and environment, preventing exploitation and abuse, and avoiding contact to prevent the spread of modern diseases. Historic exploitation has led governments to grant legal protection and land rights to uncontacted peoples, such as in the Vale do Javari in Brazil and North Sentinel Island in India. In 1961, British explorer Richard Mason was killed by the Panará tribe. Contact in 1973, when the BR-163 road was built through their territory, led to disease and environmental degradation, killing over 250 of the 350 Panará members within a year.

Contention often arises from governments’ desire to extract natural resources. In Brazil, the government attempted assimilation in the 1960s and 1970s, but in 1987, the Department of Isolated Indians (FUNAI) was created, securing protected lands. In Colombia, contact with the Nukak tribe by an evangelical group led to respiratory infections, clashes with drug traffickers, and the death of over half the tribe, resulting in government relocation and poverty. Exploitation for lumbering, ranching, oil prospecting, and poaching poses significant dangers. Former Peruvian President Alan García claimed uncontacted groups were a “fabrication of environmentalists.” In 2016, a Chinese mining subsidiary in Bolivia ignored signs of encroaching on uncontacted tribes. Missionaries can also cause great damage.

In 2014, Acre Indians contacted the Brazilian government due to threats from cocaine traffickers, indicating awareness of the outside world and strategic decisions to avoid contact. Satellite images show tribes migrating away from roads and logging. Indigenous rights activists advocate for leaving isolated peoples alone to protect their self-determination. FUNAI collaborates with experts to make controlled initial contact, operating trading posts for metal tools and cooking instruments, preventing conflicts, and delivering vaccinations. However, FUNAI reported receiving only 15% of its requested budget in 2017. In 2018, FUNAI released videos and images of tribes to raise public awareness and protect them from commercial pressures, investigating a possible mass homicide against the Flecheiros tribe.

The United Nations Human Rights Council (2009) and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (2013) introduced guidelines including the right to choose self-isolation. Reports of “human safaris” in India’s Andaman Islands and the Peruvian Amazon, where tourists seek to view uncontacted peoples, are controversial.

By Region 🔗

India 🔗

Sentinelese 🔗

The Sentinelese people of North Sentinel Island reject contact, often with lethal force. Their language differs significantly from other Andaman languages, suggesting millennia of isolation. Experts consider them the most isolated people in the world. Indian visits to the island ceased in 1997. In 2018, John Allen Chau, an American missionary, was killed while illegally visiting the island. In 2025, a US citizen was arrested for making an unauthorized landing on the island. Survival International condemned these actions, noting the vulnerability of uncontacted peoples to contact-induced diseases.

Shompen 🔗

The Shompen are the Indigenous people of Great Nicobar Island, with an estimated population of 300 in 2001. They practice a hunter-gatherer economy. Survival International identifies them as one of the most isolated peoples, with most refusing interactions with outsiders. The proposed Great Nicobar Development Plan, including an airport, international port, and industrial park, threatens their way of life. In February 2024, 39 genocide experts warned that the development would be a “death sentence” for the Shompen due to increased population and exposure to outside diseases.

South America 🔗

Bolivia 🔗

The Toromona are an uncontacted people living near the Madidi and Heath Rivers. The government has created a protected area within Madidi National Park for them. Among the Ayoreo people of the Gran Chaco, a small number of uncontacted nomadic hunter-gatherers reside in the Kaa-Iya del Gran Chaco National Park. Pacahuaras are believed to be living in voluntary isolation in Pando Department.

Brazil 🔗

Until the 1970s, Brazil attempted to move people on commercially cultivatable lands. In 1987, the Department of Isolated Indians (FUNAI) was established, and the Vale do Javari was declared perpetually sealed off. In 2007, FUNAI reported 67 uncontacted Indigenous peoples, up from 40 in 2005. The Awá people live in the eastern Amazon rainforest, with approximately 350 members, 100 of whom are uncontacted. Their tribe is at risk due to conflicts with logging interests. The Kawahiva live in northern Mato Grosso, constantly moving and known primarily from physical evidence. In 2013, the government released video of the Kawahiva filmed in 2011. In 2025, FUNAI confirmed that the demarcation of the Kawahiva do Rio Pardo territory will happen by the end of 2025. The Korubu live in the lower Vale do Javari. The Flecheiros (“arrow people”) also live in the Vale do Javari. Other tribes may include the Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau and the Himarimã.

In 2019, two brothers of the Piripkura tribe initiated contact with FUNAI after their fire went out, becoming the focus of the documentary Piripkura. Another man, the “Man of the Hole,” lived alone on 8,000 hectares, digging hundreds of holes. He was found dead in his dwelling in August 2022. Since 2021, uncontacted peoples in Brazil have been threatened by illegal land grabbers, loggers, and gold miners. The government of Jair Bolsonaro signaled its intention to develop the Amazon and reduce Indigenous reservations.

Colombia 🔗

Colombia is regarded as offering maximum protection to uncontacted Indigenous people through tribal reserves and strict patrolling. The Nukak people are nomadic hunter-gatherers living between the Guaviare and Inírida rivers. Groups, including the Carabayo, Yuri, and Passé, reside in Río Puré National Park.

Ecuador 🔗

Two isolated Indigenous peoples of Ecuador live in the Amazon region: the Tagaeri and the Taromenane, both eastern Huaorani peoples living in Yasuni National Park. These semi-nomadic people live in small groups, subsisting on hunting, gathering, and some crops. Since 2007, national policy mandates untouchability, self-determination, equality, and no contact. In 2013, more than 20 Taromenane were killed by Waorani, another Huaorani group.

Paraguay 🔗

Approximately 100 Ayoreo people, some of whom are in the Totobiegosode tribe, live uncontacted in the forest. They are nomadic hunter-gatherers in Amotocodie. They are the last uncontacted peoples south of the Amazon Basin, threatened by illegal deforestation. Brazilian company Yaguarete Porá S.A. is converting their ancestral territory into cattle ranching land. The Union of Ayoreo Natives of Paraguay is working for their protection, with support from the Iniciativa Amotocodie. In 2021, the Ayoreo appealed to the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights to save their land.

Peru 🔗

The Nomole (Mashco-Piro) are nomadic Arawak-speaking hunter-gatherers who inhabit Manú National Park. In 1998, their number was estimated at 100 to 250. They speak a dialect of the Piro languages. Amid incursions on their land, the tribe has made it clear they do not wish to be contacted. In July 2024, video and images of dozens of uncontact

item.title: Alien
item.description:
Alien 🔗

The Alien franchise is a science fiction horror and action media franchise that began with the 1979 film Alien. The series centers on Ellen Ripley’s battles with the extraterrestrial Xenomorph and the prequel series following the android David 8 and the Engineers. The franchise is owned by 20th Century Studios.

Created by: Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett Original Work: Alien (1979) Owner: 20th Century Studios Years Active: 1979–present

Premise 🔗

The franchise depicts deadly encounters between humanity and the Xenomorph, a hostile extraterrestrial species. Humanity is a space-faring species, and space journeys require cryosleep. The megacorporation Weyland-Yutani Corp seeks to profit from the Aliens, manipulating and endangering characters. The series also explores the origin of the human race, with the Engineers sacrificing themselves to spark the genesis of mankind.

Background 🔗

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the script for Alien. Brandywine Productions bought the script, and 20th Century Fox invested millions after the success of Star Wars. The Ripley character was initially to be played by Tom Skerritt, but Sigourney Weaver was cast instead. Ridley Scott directed the film. H. R. Giger designed the alien creature and derelict ship, Mœbius created the spacesuits, and Ron Cobb provided the industrial design for the sets.

James Cameron expressed interest in continuing the Alien story in 1983. After Cameron’s The Terminator became a hit, he and Gale Anne Hurd were approved to direct and produce Aliens. Following the second film, Weaver was not interested in returning, but she was offered a $5 million salary and a producer credit to make Alien 3. Alien 3 faced script difficulties, trouble securing a director, and studio interference.

Production on Alien Resurrection began in 1996. Weaver joined the project after being offered an $11 million salary and more creative control. The script resurrected the Ripley character via human cloning. Joss Whedon later said that he thought it had done “everything wrong” with his script.

Films 🔗

This section lists the Alien films, including the original series, Alien vs. Predator films, and Prometheus films. It includes the U.S. release date, director, screenwriter(s), story by, and producer(s) for each film.

Original series 🔗

  • Alien (1979): Directed by Ridley Scott, starring Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley. The crew of the Nostromo encounters a deadly alien creature.
  • Aliens (1986): Directed by James Cameron, Ripley returns to LV-426 with a squad of marines to investigate a lost colony.
  • Alien 3 (1992): Directed by David Fincher, Ripley crash-lands on a prison planet and faces a new alien threat.
  • Alien Resurrection (1997): Directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Ripley is cloned 200 years after her death, and the military attempts to exploit the Aliens.

Crossover series 🔗

  • Alien vs. Predator (2004): Directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, a group of explorers discovers an ancient pyramid in Antarctica, where they become caught in a battle between Aliens and Predators.
  • Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem (2007): Directed by Greg & Colin Strause, the Predalien hybrid from the previous film causes a Predator ship to crash in Gunnison, Colorado, leading to a battle between Aliens and a Predator.

Prequel series 🔗

  • Prometheus (2012): Directed by Ridley Scott, scientists Elizabeth Shaw and Charlie Holloway discover a star map and travel to LV-223, where they encounter the Engineers.
  • Alien: Covenant (2017): Directed by Ridley Scott, the crew of the Covenant traces a transmission to an Engineer homeworld, where they encounter David 8 and a new breed of Alien.

Spin-off film 🔗

  • Alien: Romulus (2024): Directed by Fede Álvarez, set between Alien and Aliens.

Future 🔗

Discusses potential future installments in the Alien franchise, including a cancelled Alien 5 project by Neill Blomkamp and ongoing development of new films.

This section lists the Alien short films, including the U.S. release date, director(s), screenwriter(s), and producer(s) for each film.

Television and web series 🔗

This section lists the television and web series in the Alien franchise, including the season, episodes, originally released dates, network, showrunner(s), and status for each series.

  • Alien: Isolation – The Digital Series (2019): A seven-episode animated adaptation of the video game Alien: Isolation.
  • Alien: Earth (2025): A new TV series project based on the franchise, set on Earth in the near future.

Principal cast 🔗

Lists actors and the characters they portrayed in the films, web series, television series, and audio dramas. Key actors include Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley, Ian Holm as Ash, Lance Henriksen as Bishop II Michael Bishop Weyland, Carrie Henn as Rebecca “Newt” Jorden, Michael Biehn as Dwayne Hicks, Noomi Rapace as Elizabeth M. Shaw, and Michael Fassbender as David 8.

Reception 🔗

This section discusses the box office performance, critical and public response, and accolades received by the Alien films.

Provides a table of the box office revenue for each Alien film, including North America, foreign, and worldwide totals, as well as the budget for each film.

Provides a table of the critical and public response to each Alien film, including Rotten Tomatoes scores, Metacritic scores, and CinemaScore grades.

item.title: Pentagon UFO videos
item.description:
Pentagon UFO Videos 🔗

This article discusses the widely publicized cockpit instrumentation display videos from US Navy fighter jets, often characterized as UFOs.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the videos, referencing historical UFO photographs and events. It details the initial incident on November 14, 2004, involving Commander David Fravor of the USS Nimitz Carrier Strike Group investigating radar indications of a possible target off the coast of southern California. The USS Princeton had been tracking unusual aircraft for two weeks prior to the incident. Fravor’s account of encountering a white, oval object hovering above an ocean disturbance is highlighted, as well as the observations of other pilots. It also mentions Lieutenant Commander Chad Underwood, who recorded the “FLIR” video and coined the term “Tic Tac” to describe the object. The section also mentions the 2014-2015 incidents involving fighter pilots associated with the USS Theodore Roosevelt carrier strike group operating off the East Coast of the United States, during which the GIMBAL and GOFAST videos were recorded.

Release of Videos 🔗

This section focuses on the public release of the videos. The New York Times reported on the incidents and published the “FLIR” and “GIMBAL” videos in December 2017, while the Washington Post published the “GOFAST” video. Christopher Mellon, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence, provided the videos to the press. Luis Elizondo, the director of the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, resigned from the Pentagon in October 2017 to protest government secrecy. In September 2019, the Pentagon confirmed the videos were made by naval aviators. On April 27, 2020, the Pentagon formally released the three videos. In February 2020, the United States Navy confirmed that intelligence briefings have been provided to members of Congress.

2021 Release 🔗

This section details the release of additional footage in 2021. In April 2021, the Pentagon confirmed the authenticity of a video taken by Navy personnel aboard USS Russell in 2019, showing a triangular object. Mick West suggested the image was the result of an optical effect called a bokeh. The Pentagon also confirmed photographs of objects described as “sphere”, “acorn” and “metallic blimp”. In May 2021, a second video recorded by Navy personnel aboard the USS Omaha on July 15, 2019, was confirmed and is under review by the UAP Task Force. The video purportedly shows a spherical object flying over the ocean. Mick West commented on the video, suggesting it could simply be a plane.

2023 Release 🔗

This section covers the release of additional videos in 2023. In early 2023, an object was filmed by two MQ-9 drones in South Asia, initially believed to be anomalous but later identified as a commuter aircraft. On May 31, 2023, Sean M. Kirkpatrick shared an infrared video recorded in the western United States in 2021, which AARO concluded to be commercial aircraft. On April 19, 2023, the Pentagon released another video featuring MQ-9 drone footage from the Middle East depicting an unidentified aerial phenomenon resembling a small “metallic orb”. Sean M. Kirkpatrick briefed a Senate Armed Services subcommittee on the video, but stated they are unable to fully identify anything from the video.

Potential Explanations 🔗

This section explores potential explanations for the aerial phenomena recorded in the videos. As of 2020, the Department of Defense characterizes the phenomena as “unidentified”. Skeptical explanations include instrument malfunction, human observational error, or common aircraft. Mick West cautioned that believers in “alien disclosure” are “encroaching on these real issues of UAPs”. Adam Frank speculated that the UFOs could be drones deployed by rivals like Russia and China. Thomas Bania speculated that they could be some form of electronic warfare fielded by China or Russia. The US Navy updated its reporting guidelines for unexplained aerial observations. Senator Marco Rubio expressed concern that the UFOs may be Chinese or Russian technology. Admiral Gary Roughead said that most assessments were inconclusive. Jeff Wise suggests advancements in electronic warfare could deceive sensors. In 2023, David Fravor testified under oath regarding the USS Nimitz sighting, stating that the technology was far superior to anything the US had.

June 2021 UFO Report 🔗

This section discusses the preliminary report on UAPs released by the US Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) on June 25, 2021. The report came to no conclusion about what the UAPs were, citing a lack of sufficient data. Some UAPs appeared to exhibit unusual flight characteristics, including high velocity and maneuverability. The report indicated that the UAP recordings probably were of physical objects and proposed five possible categories of explanation: airborne clutter, natural atmospheric phenomena, US government or industry development technology, foreign craft, and an “Other” category. The report raised concerns about safety and security issues and indicated that investigation of the topic would continue.

FOI Request by The Black Vault 🔗

This section details a Freedom of Information request made by The Black Vault for the release of more video footage. The government confirmed it had more footage but refused to release it, citing concerns for national security. Gregory Cason stated that the release of this information would harm national security.

In Popular Culture 🔗

This section notes the videos’ appearance in the History Channel series Unidentified: Inside America’s UFO Investigation and an interview with Fravor on The Joe Rogan Experience.

See Also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program, Unidentified Aerial Phenomena Task Force, All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, Navy UFO patents, and the film The Phenomenon.
