item.title: Barney and Betty Hill incident
item.description:
Barney and Betty Hill Incident 🔗

This Wikipedia article details the alleged alien abduction of Barney and Betty Hill in 1961, a case that gained significant notoriety and influenced the alien abduction narrative. The article covers the background of the Hills, the details of their reported encounter, the aftermath, analysis of the star map Betty Hill claimed to have seen, and the cultural impact of their story.

Background 🔗

Barney and Betty Hill were an interracial couple living in Portsmouth, New Hampshire. Barney was a postal worker and Betty was a social worker. They were active in civil rights and community affairs. The article also mentions that they are the grandparents of UFC fighter Angela Hill.

UFO Encounter 🔗

On September 19-20, 1961, the Hills claimed to have encountered a UFO while driving back from a vacation in Canada. Near Lancaster, New Hampshire, Betty noticed a bright light in the sky. They stopped near Twin Mountain to observe the object, which Betty viewed through binoculars. Barney initially thought it was a commercial airliner, but it rapidly descended towards them. They continued driving, observing the object near Cannon Mountain and the Old Man of the Mountain. South of Indian Head, the object descended rapidly, causing Barney to stop the car. He observed humanoid figures through binoculars. Fearing capture, Barney ran back to the car, and as they drove away, they heard beeping sounds and experienced a daze. They reported the incident to NICAP investigator Walter Webb.

Immediate Aftermath 🔗

Upon arriving home, the Hills noted odd sensations and unexplained occurrences. Betty insisted on keeping their luggage near the back door. Their watches stopped working. Barney found the binocular strap torn and his shoes scraped. They both took showers to remove possible contamination and drew pictures of what they had seen. Betty’s dress was torn and had a pinkish powder on it. Shiny, concentric circles appeared on their car’s trunk, which affected a compass.

Initial Report to the U.S. Air Force and NICAP 🔗

Walter N. Webb, a Boston astronomer and NICAP member, interviewed the Hills. Barney mentioned a “mental block” and suspected he was suppressing parts of the event. Webb concluded that they were truthful, and the incident likely occurred as reported.

Betty’s Dreams 🔗

Ten days after the encounter, Betty began experiencing vivid dreams for five consecutive nights. In her dreams, they encountered a roadblock and were forced into a forest by small men in blue uniforms. The men appeared nearly human with greyish skin. They were eventually returned to their car and watched the craft depart.

Medical Help and More Interviews 🔗

The Hills sought medical help to understand their experience.

Missing Time 🔗

During a follow-up interview with NICAP members C.D. Jackson and Robert E. Hohmann, the Hills realized they had “missing time” – a period of about seven hours they couldn’t account for. They recalled almost nothing of a 35-mile stretch of road and an image of a fiery orb.

Private Disclosure 🔗

In 1962, the Hills privately disclosed their encounter to Captain Ben H. Swett of the United States Air Force, who was interested in the “missing time” aspect.

Simon’s Hypnosis Sessions 🔗

The Hills underwent hypnosis with Dr. Benjamin Simon to recover their memories.

Barney’s Sessions 🔗

Under hypnosis, Barney recalled the binocular strap breaking as he ran from the UFO. He remembered being compelled to drive into the woods and seeing six men. He described the beings’ terrifying eyes and their communication through “thought transference.”

Betty’s Sessions 🔗

Betty’s account under hypnosis was similar to her dreams, with some differences. The technology on the craft was different, the short men differed significantly in physical appearance and the sequential order of the abduction differed. Barney’s and Betty’s memories in hypnotic regression were consistent with one another.

Simon’s Conclusions 🔗

Dr. Simon concluded that the case was a psychological aberration.

Post-Hypnosis Publicity and Barney’s and Betty’s Death 🔗

The Hills initially kept a low profile. However, in 1965, a front-page story in the Boston Traveller revealed their story, leading to international attention. John G. Fuller wrote the book The Interrupted Journey about the case in 1966. Barney died in 1969, and Betty became a figure in the UFO community. Betty died in 2004.

Analyzing the Star Map 🔗

In 1968, Marjorie Fish, an amateur astronomer, attempted to decipher the star map Betty Hill had drawn. Fish constructed a three-dimensional model of nearby Sun-like stars and concluded that the map’s perspective matched the Zeta Reticuli star system. The analysis was debated, with Carl Sagan arguing it was a random alignment of points. Later, more accurate data from the Hipparcos mission led Fish to reject her hypothesis.

Interrupted Journey 🔗

The 1966 book Interrupted Journey by John G. Fuller detailed the Hills’ claims. Betty Hill’s niece, Kathleen Marden, further explored these themes in Captured! The Betty and Barney Hill UFO Experience.

Rebutting the Hills 🔗

Jim Macdonald argued that the Hills’ experience was caused by misinterpreting an aircraft warning beacon on Cannon Mountain, combined with stress, sleep deprivation, and false memories. Robert Sheaffer criticized Betty Hill’s credibility, citing her UFO photos and later delusional stories.

Influence from The Outer Limits 🔗

Martin Kottmeyer suggested that Barney’s memories might have been influenced by “The Bellero Shield,” an episode of The Outer Limits. Jason Colavito pointed out other episodes of The Outer Limits that aired before Barney’s hypnosis sessions that were even more reminiscent of the Hill’s story.

In Popular Media 🔗

The Hills’ story has been depicted in various forms of media.

Nonfictional Accounts 🔗

Barney Hill appeared on To Tell the Truth in 1966. Kathleen Marden and Stanton Friedman authored Captured in 2004.

In Fiction 🔗

The 1975 film The UFO Incident dramatized the Hills’ abduction. The story has also been referenced in comic books, films like Prometheus, virtual reality exhibits, and television series like Project Blue Book.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betty_and_Barney_Hill_abduction

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials 🔗

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” which are names given in ufology to humanoid races purportedly from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention pale-blue/grey or pastel purple skin tones. George Adamski is noted as one of the first to report contact with these beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding them often includes telepathy, benevolence, and physical beauty.

History 🔗

This section discusses the historical context and cultural influences related to the Nordic alien phenomenon. David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” associating Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection. These aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned with Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal and youthful. While popular in the 1950s, claims of encounters became less common as the grey alien archetype rose to prominence.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted 🔗

This section lists books written by individuals who claim to have had personal contact with Nordic aliens. These include Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski, From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger, The Walton Experience by Travis Walton, and Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites). The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions as “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends.”

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials 🔗

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” a type of humanoid extraterrestrial beings often discussed in ufology. These beings are said to originate from the Pleiades star cluster and are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans. They are typically depicted as taller than average humans (6-7 ft), with blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention skin tones of pale blue/grey or pastel purple.

George Adamski, a Polish-American ufologist, is noted as one of the first to publicly claim contact with Nordic beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding these beings often includes themes of telepathy, benevolence, beauty, and grace. Telepathy is often described as the primary form of communication.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical context and cultural influences surrounding the Nordic alien narrative.

Cultural historian David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories of Nordic-type aliens. The film features an extraterrestrial arriving on Earth to warn humanity about the dangers of atomic weapons.

Bates College professor Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” noting that Nordic aliens are often associated with spiritual growth, love, and protection among believers.

Nordic aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned about Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal, watchful, smiling, affectionate, and youthful.

Claims of encounters with Nordic aliens were common in Europe during the 1950s but became less frequent in later decades, as the grey alien became more prevalent in extraterrestrial encounter accounts.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted 🔗

This section lists books written by individuals who claim to have had personal contact with Nordic aliens.

The books mentioned include:

  • Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski
  • From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger
  • The Walton Experience by Travis Walton
  • Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites)

The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions as “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends”.

item.title: List of humanoid aliens
item.description:
List of Humanoid Aliens 🔗

This Wikipedia entry is a compilation of fictional extraterrestrial humanoid characters from various media. It emphasizes that these aliens possess human-like traits such as upright posture, bipedalism, opposable thumbs, and facial features. The list is organized by medium: Animation, Comics, Film, Literature, Television, and Video Games. Each entry includes the character’s name, origin (the work in which they appear), and brief notes about their role or characteristics. The article is flagged as needing additional citations for verification and may not be complete.

Animation 🔗

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in animated works. Key characters include:

  • The Great Gazoo (The Flintstones): A tiny alien exiled to Earth who can only be seen by Fred, Barney, children, and animals.
  • Cure Princess/Hime Shirayuki (HappinessCharge PreCure!): A princess from the Blue Sky Kingdom.
  • Mikitaka Hazekura (JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure): An alien who appears as a teenage boy with pointed ears.
  • Interplanet Janet (Schoolhouse Rock): A cyborg girl from another galaxy.
  • Jet Propulsion (Ready Jet Go!): An alien from Bortron 7 studying Earth.
  • Cure Milky/Lala Hagoromo (Star Twinkle PreCure): An alien from the planet Samaan.
  • Little Twelvetoes (Schoolhouse Rock): A jovial alien with green skin and six fingers and toes.
  • Marvin the Martian (Looney Tunes): A Martian often accompanied by his dog K-9.
  • Ozmodiar (The Simpsons): A parody of The Great Gazoo, only visible to Homer Simpson.
  • Roger (American Dad!): An alien living in Stan’s attic.
  • Sailor Starlights (Sailor Moon): Sailor Guardians from Planet Kinmoku.
  • Shadow Galactica (Sailor Moon): Antagonists from various planets in the Milky Way.
  • Son Goku (Dragon Ball): A Saiyan from Planet Vegeta.
  • Cure Cosmo/Yuni (Star Twinkle PreCure): A shapeshifting catgirl from Planet Rainbow.
  • Zim (Invader Zim): An Irken invader sent to conquer Earth.
  • Upgrade (Ben 10): A Galvanic Mechamorph from Galvan B.
  • Atomix (Ben 10): An alien from an unknown planet who can create nuclear energy.

Comics 🔗

This section details humanoid aliens from comic books. Notable entries include:

  • Annihilus (Fantastic Four): A villain from the Marvel Universe. Created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby.
  • Cosmo (Cosmo the Merry Martian): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Bob White.
  • Darna (Darna): An extraterrestrial warrior who manifests in a human girl. Created by Mars Ravelo and Nestor Redondo.
  • Khâny (Yoko Tsuno): An alien from the planet Vinea. Created by Roger Leloup.
  • Plunk (Plunk): An alien from the planet Smurk. Created by Luc Cromheecke and Laurent Letzer.
  • The Scrameustache (Scrameustache): An alien with a cat-like face. Created by Roland Goossens (Gos).
  • Mr. Skygack (Mr. Skygack, from Mars): A Martian studying human behavior. Created by A.D. Condo.
  • Superman/Clark Kent (Action Comics #1): An alien from Krypton with superhuman powers. Created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster.
  • Xal-Kor (Xal-Kor the Human Cat): An alien from Felis who can transform between cat, hybrid, and human forms. Created by Grass Green.
  • Zook (Zook): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Jack Miller and Joe Certa.

Film 🔗

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in movies. Key examples include:

  • E.T. (E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial): An alien who befriends a human boy.
  • Various (Marvel Cinematic Universe): Includes Asgardians, members of the Guardians of the Galaxy, and Eternals.
  • Klaatu (The Day the Earth Stood Still): An alien who delivers a peaceful message to Earth.
  • Various (Star Wars): Includes Chewbacca, Yoda, Darth Maul, and Ahsoka Tano.
  • Zaphod Beeblebrox (The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy): An alien from near Betelgeuse.
  • Mork (Mork and Mindy): An alien from Ork who studies humanity on Earth.
  • The Alien Girl (Super Deluxe): An alien living on Earth, mingling with humans.

Literature 🔗

  • Gonzo (The Muppet Show): A puppet revealed to be of extraterrestrial origin.
  • Mork (Mork & Mindy): An alien from Ork who befriends a human woman.
  • Martin O’Hara (My Favorite Martian): A Martian anthropologist stranded on Earth.
  • Dick Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Harry Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.

  • Tommy Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Spock (Star Trek): A Vulcan science officer on the Enterprise.
  • Ultraman (Ultraman): A race of aliens who protect the universe.

Video Games 🔗

item.title: UFO reports and atomic sites
item.description:
Correlation between UFO reports and atomic sites 🔗

This article explores the historical and statistical connections between reports of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) and locations associated with atomic technology, primarily in the United States. It examines how early speculation linked UFO sightings to atomic sites, the influence of the Cold War, and various incidents and studies that have fueled this correlation.

Background 🔗

This section establishes the context for the link between UFO reports and atomic sites. It highlights the increased scrutiny of US airspace due to national security concerns in 1947, coinciding with increased media coverage of UFO reports. It notes that the development of atomic weapons and long-range vehicles meant that even a small number of adversarial overflights could have significant national security implications.

1940s weapons development 🔗

This section details the development of atomic weapons by the US during World War II as part of the Manhattan Project. Key locations mentioned are Oak Ridge, Tennessee (uranium enrichment), Hanford, Washington (plutonium production), and Los Alamos, New Mexico (bomb design and construction). It also discusses the increased lethality and range of air power during the war and Japan’s deployment of intercontinental balloon bombs, one of which interfered with plutonium production at Hanford. The US’s Project Mogul, inspired by the Japanese balloons, aimed to detect Soviet atomic tests. The section also mentions German advancements in rockets, jet fighters, and bomber designs, which both the US and Soviet governments learned about and utilized after the war.

Increased scrutiny of US airspace 🔗

This section explains how the possibility of a Soviet atomic attack led to increased surveillance of US airspace, particularly around atomic facilities. It mentions the development of the first intercontinental bomber, the Convair B-36 Peacemaker, which could reach the Soviet Union from American soil. Atomic sites were among the first locations in the US to operate radar, supported by visual spotters and fighter squadrons. The start of the Cold War in 1947 influenced media coverage of UFO reports, treating them as potential national security threats rather than folklore or tall tales.

Chronology 🔗

This section presents a timeline of notable UFO incidents and their connection to atomic sites, starting in 1947.

Supposed flying discs allegedly break sound barrier 🔗

This section focuses on the Kenneth Arnold sighting in June 1947, where he reported seeing nine objects flying at supersonic speeds near Mount Rainier and Mount Adams in Washington state. The proximity of this sighting to the Hanford plutonium plant led to media speculation about a connection. The section also notes that the sound barrier was not officially broken until October 1947 by Chuck Yeager, and the Air Force initially denied the achievement.

Roswell and atomic weapons 🔗

This section discusses the Roswell incident in July 1947, where debris was found on a ranch near Corona, New Mexico. The 509th at Roswell was the Army’s atomic bomb group. The initial explanation of a weather balloon was later questioned, and the Air Force eventually concluded the debris came from a Project Mogul balloon designed to detect Soviet atomic tests.

Public claims of link to atomic sites 🔗

This section covers the public’s perception of a link between flying discs and atomic weaponry in 1947. It mentions headlines claiming a connection between “discs” and “atom products,” citing an unnamed scientist from the Manhattan Project who suggested experiments in atomic energy transmutation were responsible for the sightings. The Hanford works were also mentioned as a location with numerous UFO reports. Atomic scientists Harold Urey and David E. Lilienthal dismissed these claims as “gibberish.”

Mantell crash near Oak Ridge 🔗

This section details the Mantell incident in January 1948, where Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a pilot from Fort Knox, Kentucky, crashed while pursuing a UFO near Oak Ridge, Tennessee. The Air Force later attributed the UFO to a Skyhook balloon, a classified project.

Green Fireballs near Hanford 🔗

This section discusses reports of green fireballs near Hanford, Washington, starting in December 1948. It mentions Lincoln LaPaz’s investigation of these reports and the issuance of orders to fire on potentially hostile aircraft over Hanford and Oak Ridge. The section also notes UFO reports over Hanford and Oak Ridge during the early days of the Korean War and a 1952 Life Magazine article reporting unusual radar returns near an atomic installation.

Contactees and nuclear war 🔗

This section discusses the theme of nuclear war in UFO culture. The 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still featured a benevolent spaceman warning about atomic weapons. George Adamski began claiming contact with “space brothers” concerned about atomic weapons.

Big Sur missile test 🔗

This section describes a reported UFO incident during a 1964 Air Force missile test near Big Sur, California. Robert Jacobs, who oversaw the team, claimed a UFO interfered with the test. Kingston George, the project engineer, argued the team had actually recorded the release of decoy warheads and chaff.

Malmstrom missile malfunction 🔗

This section discusses UFO reports over a missile complex in March 1967 during a routine malfunction. Retired Air Force personnel later claimed the weapons failure was caused by a UFO.

Hynek suggests atomic link 🔗

This section notes that astronomer J. Allen Hynek, initially hired by the Air Force to debunk UFO reports, began speculating in 1968 that UFOs might be related to an unknown phenomenon connected to nuclear energy.

Rendelsham 🔗

This section describes the Rendlesham Forest incident in December 1980, a series of reported sightings of unexplained lights near RAF Woodbridge in England, which was used by the United States Air Force (USAF). USAF personnel, including Lieutenant Colonel Charles I. Halt, claimed to see things they described as a UFO.

21st century 🔗

This section covers more recent developments, including a legend that the 1945 Trinity atomic bomb test brought down an alien spacecraft. It mentions Robert Hastings’ book UFOs & Nukes: Extraordinary Encounters at Nuclear Weapons Sites and claims by former AATIP director Luis Elizondo and former U.S. Air Force personnel that UAPs have interfered with nuclear capabilities. It also notes reports of UFOs interfering with other major powers’ nuclear weapons systems. The section mentions the U.S. National Defense Authorization Act requesting more information on UAP incidents associated with military nuclear assets and claims by Robert L. Salas and Robert Hastings of alien abduction. Finally, it mentions that the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission will raise the issue of UAP with its United States counterpart.

Statistical studies 🔗

This section examines the statistical evidence for a correlation between UFO reports and atomic sites, considering the possibility of observational bias.

It introduces the concept of the “streetlight effect,” where observations are more likely to be reported where observations are most likely to occur. Mainstream experts argue that increased scrutiny of airspace around strategically important facilities explains the correlation.

The section mentions a rudimentary spatial analysis conducted by Air Force officers in the 1950s, which found that UFOs were seen more frequently around areas vital to US defense, such as Los Alamos-Albuquerque, Oak Ridge, and White Sands Proving Ground.

A 2015 study of UFO reports in France concluded that there was a statistically significant link between nuclear activities and unexplained UFO reports.

A 2021 document from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence suggested that clustering of UFO reports around US training and testing grounds might be due to “collection bias as a result of focused attention.”

A 2023 study examined a National UFO Reporting Center dataset and found that UFO reports are more frequent in areas with darker nighttime skies and “wide-open spaces.” Additionally, analysis suggested that proximity to airports and military installations was linked to increased UFO reports.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_reports_and_atomic_sites

item.title: First contact (science fiction)
item.description:
First Contact (Science Fiction) 🔗

First contact is a recurring theme in science fiction, exploring the initial meeting between humans and extraterrestrial life or any sentient species from different planets or natural satellites. It draws parallels with the anthropological concept of first contact.

History 🔗

The concept dates back to the 2nd century AD with Lucian of Samosata’s A True Story. Voltaire’s Le Micromégas (1752) features an alien from Sirius visiting Earth and engaging in philosophical discussions with humans. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds is traditionally credited with popularizing the trope of conflict between humans and alien intelligent species, although earlier examples exist, such as Les Xipéhuz.

The 1950s saw a surge in first contact stories in the United States, often reflecting Cold War anxieties about nuclear holocaust or communist invasion. Films like The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) began to portray first contact as potentially beneficial, while Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956) reflected fears of communist infiltration.

Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End depicts both positive and negative consequences of first contact, while Stanisław Lem’s Solaris explores the futility of communication with extraterrestrial intelligence.

The Star Trek franchise introduced the Prime Directive, a non-interference regulation, which has since become a common trope in science fiction.

Later works include Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Carl Sagan’s Contact (1985), and novels like The Sparrow (1996) and The Three-Body Problem (2006). Films like Arrival (2016) focus on the linguistic challenges of first contact. Project Hail Mary (2021) depicts an unintended first contact scenario.

Types and Themes 🔗

First contact stories vary widely in their methods of contact and the nature of the subsequent interaction. These variations include positive vs. negative outcomes, physical meetings vs. message interception, and more.

Alien Invasion 🔗

Alien invasion is a common early trope, popularized by The War of the Worlds. During the Cold War, these stories often reflected American anxieties about the Soviet Union, with infiltration narratives being a variation on the theme.

Alien Artifacts 🔗

Bracewell probes, hypothesized by Ronald N. Bracewell, are extraterrestrial artifacts that allow real-time communication. Big Dumb Objects, such as megastructures like ringworlds, are a common variation. 2001: A Space Odyssey features mysterious black Monoliths that enhance technological progress. Stories also involve finding alien spacecraft, such as in Rendezvous with Rama.

Communication with Alien Intelligence 🔗

Many stories deal with the challenges of communication. Stanisław Lem’s works often portray mutual understanding between humans and aliens as impossible, criticizing the idea of cognitive universality.

Message from Space 🔗

First contact may occur through the detection of an extraterrestrial signal or technosignature. The search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) began with the advent of radio.

Alien Languages 🔗

Languages are a common form of communication with aliens, and many stories explore language issues. While space operas often use universal translators, hard science fiction typically depicts the difficulties of communicating with aliens, which can lead to misunderstandings and even war.

Ethics of First Contact 🔗

Many writers have considered how humans should treat aliens upon first contact. The Prime Directive of Star Trek is a notable example of non-interference. In Soviet science fiction, “progressors” worked clandestinely to improve less advanced civilizations.

Notable Examples 🔗

The Day the Earth Stood Still 🔗

Based on the short story “Farewell to the Master,” The Day the Earth Stood Still depicts the arrival of Klaatu and Gort in Washington, D.C. Humanity’s hostile response to first contact is used as an allegory for the Second Red Scare.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind 🔗

This 1977 film by Steven Spielberg tells the story of Roy Neary, whose life changes after an encounter with a UFO. The film was deemed “culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant” by the Library of Congress.

Contact 🔗

Carl Sagan’s 1985 novel, later adapted into a film, depicts the reception of a radio signal from Vega and the construction of a Machine based on the message’s specifications.

Star Trek 🔗

First contact is central to Starfleet operations in the Star Trek franchise. The Prime Directive is a foundational regulation, though it is frequently violated.

Star Trek: The Original Series 🔗

The original pilot episode features the Talosians. The Prime Directive was introduced in “The Return of the Archons” to prevent negative consequences from contact with technologically inferior societies.

Star Trek: The Next Generation 🔗

The pilot episode, “Encounter at Farpoint,” depicts first contact with the Q Continuum. Episodes like “Who Watches the Watchers” and “First Contact” center on the Prime Directive.

Star Trek: First Contact 🔗

This 1996 film portrays first contact between humans and Vulcans, leading to the formation of the United Federation of Planets.

The War of the Worlds 🔗

H.G. Wells’ novel details a conflict between humankind and Martians. It has been adapted into numerous films, radio dramas, and other media. The 1938 radio drama, directed by Orson Welles, reportedly caused panic among listeners.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_contact_(science_fiction)

item.title: Travis Walton incident
item.description:
The Travis Walton Incident 🔗

The Travis Walton incident is an alleged alien abduction that occurred on November 5, 1975, involving American forestry worker Travis Walton in the Apache–Sitgreaves National Forests near Heber, Arizona. The incident is widely considered a hoax.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the alleged abduction, noting that in the early 1970s, the National Enquirer tabloid offered a substantial prize for proof of extraterrestrial visitors, which may have motivated the hoax.

Travis Walton and the Turkey Springs forestry job 🔗

This section details the circumstances surrounding Travis Walton’s employment and the forestry contract. Key points include:

  • Location: The forestry job was located in Turkey Springs, about 12 miles south of Heber, Arizona. The crew lived in Snowflake, 30 miles away.
  • People: Travis Walton, his brother Duane, and crew chief Michael H. Rogers are central figures.
  • Financial Motive: Rogers’s forestry contract was behind schedule, potentially leading to financial penalties. The section notes that Walton had a prior criminal record.
  • Contract Details: The Turkey Springs job involved thinning 1,277 acres by August 1975, later extended to November 10. Failure to complete the job could result in a $2,500 penalty.

Barney Hill and NBC’s The UFO Incident 🔗

This section highlights the potential influence of the 1975 NBC television movie The UFO Incident, which dramatized the alleged abduction of Barney and Betty Hill. It suggests that the film may have inspired Walton and Rogers to fabricate their own abduction story. Skeptics and psychologists are quoted arguing that the film could have motivated someone to claim an abduction for attention. It also mentions that Travis Walton told his mother not to worry if he were ever abducted by aliens because he would return safe and sound.

Incident 🔗

This section outlines the events of November 5, 1975, when Michael H. Rogers reported Travis Walton missing. The crew claimed they saw a lit object near the roadway, Walton approached it, and was struck by a light. The crew drove away in fear and returned to find Walton and the object gone. The police were notified, and a search was initiated. Deputy Kenneth Coplan noted the calm reaction of Walton’s mother to the news of his disappearance.

Missing person investigation 🔗

This section details the search efforts and initial investigation following Walton’s disappearance. Key points include:

  • Search Party: A search party of nearly 50 people scoured the Turkey Springs area without success.
  • Family’s Reaction: Law enforcement were surprised by the calm reaction of Travis’s mother, who believed he was no longer on Earth.
  • UFO Interest: It was revealed that Travis, Duane, and their mother were interested in UFOs.
  • Polygraph Tests: Rogers and the crew underwent polygraph examinations to determine if they had harmed Walton. Five were deemed truthful, while one was inconclusive.
  • Act of God Clause: Rogers discussed the Forestry contract and the potential for an “Act of God” clause to excuse the delay.

Walton returns 🔗

This section describes Walton’s reappearance and subsequent events. Key points include:

  • Return: Walton called his sister’s home from a payphone in Heber, Arizona, on November 12, shortly after midnight.
  • Deputy Glen Flake: Deputy Flake witnessed Duane Walton transferring fuel from one car to another after having forgotten to purchase gas before local stations closed. Flake did not reveal that they knew Travis had returned home, and Duane did not tell the deputy that Travis had been found.
  • Medical Attention: Duane sought medical attention for Travis, consulting with a hypnotherapist and later two medical doctors who were also amateur UFO investigators.
  • Sheriff Gillespie: Sheriff Gillespie insisted on interviewing Travis, but Duane and Travis demanded that the interview not be recorded.
  • National Enquirer: The National Enquirer provided a suite at the Sheraton Inn in Scottsdale in exchange for exclusive access to Walton and his story.
  • Polygraph Test: Travis skipped a polygraph interview with police, but was later interviewed by Jack McCarthy a free-lance polygraph examiner arranged by a UFO group and the Enquirer. McCarthy concluded that Travis was engaged in a “gross deception”.
  • Television Interview: Walton appeared on Phoenix television, claiming he lost consciousness and awoke in a hospital-like room with short, bald creatures.

Publicity and popular culture 🔗

This section covers the media attention and cultural impact of the Walton incident. Key points include:

  • National Enquirer Prize: The National Enquirer awarded Walton and his co-workers a $5,000 prize for “best UFO case of the year.”
  • Skepticism: Skeptics, including Philip J. Klass, viewed the story as a hoax for financial gain.
  • Book and Film: Walton wrote The Walton Experience in 1978, which was adapted into the 1993 film Fire in the Sky.
  • Media Appearances: Walton has appeared at UFO conventions and on television, including The Moment of Truth and the Joe Rogan Experience podcast.

Rogers-Walton dispute of 2021 🔗

This section details a public dispute between Mike Rogers and Travis Walton in 2021. Rogers initially recanted his status as a witness to the abduction, claiming it was a hoax, but later reconciled with Walton and retracted his confession.

Modern views 🔗

This section presents contemporary perspectives on the Walton incident.

Waltons as UFO buffs and pranksters 🔗

This section highlights the Walton family’s interest in UFOs and their reputation for pranks. It suggests that the incident may have been planned by Travis Walton and Mike Rogers. Crew member Steve Pierce expressed suspicion that the incident had been a hoax.

National Enquirer misrepresented polygraph results 🔗

This section notes that the National Enquirer publicized the opinion of a private polygraph examiner who reported the witnesses as being truthful, but omitted all mention of Walton’s prior polygraph examiner who concluded Walton was being “grossly deceptive”.

Contrast with alien abduction syndrome 🔗

This section contrasts Walton’s account with typical alien abduction narratives, noting that Walton didn’t report paralysis, recovered memories, or other common elements.

Possible role of fire lookout tower 🔗

This section presents Robert Sheaffer’s hypothesis that Rogers and the Waltons used a nearby fire lookout tower to create the illusion of a UFO. Sheaffer suggests that Travis walked towards the tower, which was brightly lit, and an accomplice illuminated him with a spotlight.

See also 🔗

This section lists related topics, including lists of reported UFO sightings and solved missing person cases.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travis_Walton_UFO_incident

item.title: Crop circle
item.description:
Crop Circle 🔗

A crop circle, crop formation, or corn circle is a pattern created by flattening a crop, usually a cereal. The term was first coined in the early 1980s. While fringe theorists suggest obscure natural causes or alien origins, there is no scientific evidence for such explanations, and all crop circles are consistent with human causation.

History 🔗

This section details the historical accounts of crop circles and related phenomena, dividing it into periods before the 20th century, the 20th century, and the 21st century.

Before the 20th century 🔗

This subsection covers early reports that could be considered precursors to modern crop circles. It mentions a 1678 news pamphlet, The Mowing-Devil, which describes a crop whose stalks were cut in a circular pattern. It also references a 1686 report by naturalist Robert Plot on rings of mushrooms, proposing air flows as a cause. An 1880 letter to Nature by John Rand Capron describes circles of flattened crops possibly caused by “cyclonic wind action.”

20th century 🔗

This subsection details observations and reports of crop circles and similar phenomena throughout the 20th century. It mentions a 1932 observation by archaeologist E. C. Curwen of dark rings in a field. David Wood reported making crop circles in 1940. Patrick Moore described circular areas of flattened wheat near a crater in Wiltshire in 1963, suggesting air currents as a cause. Reports of UFO sightings and circular formations in swamp reeds and sugarcane fields in Tully, Queensland, Australia, and in Canada during the 1960s are noted. The 1966 Tully “saucer nest” case is described, where a farmer reported witnessing a saucer-shaped craft leaving a circular area of flattened grass. British pranksters Doug Bower and Dave Chorley claimed to have started creating crop circles in 1978, inspired by the Tully case. The 1974 film Phase IV is mentioned as a possible inspiration for the pranksters. The late 1970s saw an increase in crop circle reports, which became widely known in the late 1980s. By 2001, approximately 10,000 crop circles had been reported internationally.

21st century 🔗

This subsection covers the evolution of crop circles in the 21st century. It notes that crop formations have increased in size and complexity, with some featuring thousands of shapes and incorporating complex mathematical and scientific characteristics. Jeremy Northcote’s research found that crop circles in the UK tend to appear near roads, populated areas, and cultural heritage monuments, suggesting human causation.

Bower and Chorley 🔗

This section focuses on Doug Bower and Dave Chorley, who claimed to have started the crop circle phenomenon in 1978. They used simple tools like a plank of wood, rope, and a wire-fitted baseball cap. In 1991, they demonstrated their method to journalists. A “cereologist,” Pat Delgado, declared their circle authentic before it was revealed as a hoax. Bower and Chorley claimed responsibility for all circles made prior to 1987 and over 200 crop circles between 1978 and 1991.

Art and business 🔗

This section discusses the artistic and commercial aspects of crop circles. It notes that after simple circles in the 1970s, increasingly complex geometric designs have been created, sometimes to attract tourists. The UK arts collective Circlemakers, founded by Rod Dickinson and John Lundberg, has been creating crop circles as art and for commercial clients. The Led Zeppelin Boxed Set features an image of a crop circle. A crop-circle-making competition was held in Berkshire in 1992. In 2002, the Discovery Channel commissioned MIT graduate students to create crop circles. In 2009, The Guardian reported that crop circle activity was waning in Wiltshire as makers preferred creating promotional crop circles for companies. The 2012 Summer Olympics opening ceremony featured crop circles in the shape of the Olympic rings. A Star Wars Rebel Alliance emblem crop circle was created in California in 2017.

Legal implications 🔗

This section outlines the legal consequences related to creating crop circles. In 1992, Gábor Takács and Róbert Dallos were sued for creating a crop circle in Hungary, but the judge ruled they were only responsible for the damage within the circle itself. In 2000, Matthew Williams became the first person in the UK arrested for causing criminal damage after making a crop circle and was fined.

Creation 🔗

This section explores the various explanations for how crop circles are created, dividing it into human origins, natural origins, and alternative explanations.

Human origin 🔗

This subsection details the scientific consensus that crop circles are constructed by humans as hoaxes, advertising, or art. The most common method involves using a rope and board to flatten the plants. Skeptics point out that all characteristics of crop circles are compatible with human creation. Bower and Chorley’s confession is mentioned, as well as the increasing complexity of circles after their revelation. The main criticism of non-human creation is the lack of evidence, while many are known to be human-made. Cases where researchers declared circles “real” only to be confronted with the hoaxers are noted. Carl Sagan concluded that crop circles were created by Bower and Chorley and their copycats. Scientific American published an article by Matt Ridley, who described how easy it is to create convincing crop circles. Some crop formations are paid for by companies for advertising. Hoaxers have been caught in the process of making new circles.

Natural origins 🔗

This subsection explores natural explanations for crop circles, including weather and animal activity.

Weather 🔗

This sub-subsection discusses the suggestion that crop circles may be the result of meteorological phenomena like tornadoes or ball lightning, but there is no evidence of this. John Rand Capron blamed circles on a storm in 1880. Terence Meaden proposed that whirlwinds caused the circles. Stephen Hawking said that crop circles are either hoaxes or formed by vortex movement of air. Meaden conceded that complex designs were made by hoaxers after Bower and Chorley’s confession.

Animal activity 🔗

This sub-subsection mentions that wallabies in Tasmania have been found creating crop circles in fields of opium poppies after consuming them.

Alternative explanations 🔗

This section covers alternative, less conventional explanations for crop circles, including paranormal theories.

Paranormal 🔗

This subsection discusses paranormal, ufological, and anomalistic speculations about crop circles, ranging from bizarre meteorological phenomena to messages from extraterrestrial beings. Some speculate that crop circles are related to ley lines. Some paranormal advocates believe that ball lightning causes crop circles and that the patterns are controlled by some entity, such as Gaia, God, supernatural beings, the collective minds of humanity, or extraterrestrial beings. The Indonesian National Institute of Aeronautics and Space (LAPAN) described crop circles as “man-made.” Sceptical groups and scientists criticize hypothetical explanations as pseudoscientific. No credible evidence of extraterrestrial origin has been presented.

Changes to crops 🔗

This subsection discusses claims by some scientists that there are differences between crops inside and outside the circles, suggesting they were not man-made. William Levengood published papers finding deformities in the grain inside the circles correlated to their position. Joe Nickell objected that correlation is not causation and criticized Levengood’s methods and assumptions. Advocates of non-human causes dismiss on-site evidence of human involvement as attempts to discredit the phenomena.

Related art 🔗

This section briefly mentions that patterns similar to crop circles can also be made in snow or sand. Images can be made in forests by cutting trees.

Folklore 🔗

This section explores the connection between modern crop circles and old folkloric tales. Crop circles are culture-dependent, appearing mostly in developed and secularized Western countries. Fungi can cause circular areas of crop to die, which may be the origin of tales of “fairie rings.” A 17th-century English woodcut, the Mowing-Devil, depicts the devil mowing a circular design in a field of oats. In the 1948 German story Die zwölf Schwäne, a farmer finds a circular ring of flattened grain in his field every morning, caused by princesses disguised as swans dancing.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crop_circle

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts 🔗

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected the development of cultures, technologies, religions, and even human biology. A common idea is that deities in many religions were actually extraterrestrials, and their advanced technologies were seen as divine powers by early humans.

This idea is rejected by academics and archaeologists, who consider it pseudoarchaeology and unscientific. Claims are often based on distorted or fabricated evidence. Some critics argue that ancient astronaut theories have racist implications, diminishing the achievements of indigenous cultures.

Notable proponents in the late 20th century include Robert Charroux, Jacques Bergier, Jean Sendy, Erich von Däniken, Alexander Kazantsev, Zecharia Sitchin, Robert K. G. Temple, Giorgio A. Tsoukalos, David Hatcher Childress, Peter Kolosimo, and Mauro Biglino.

Overview 🔗

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI.

Believers often claim that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence that landed on Earth in the past. They suggest that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these ancient alien visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents also claim that extraterrestrials built or helped humans build structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island. Evidence is said to come from gaps in historical and archaeological records, as well as artifacts that are considered anachronistic and beyond the technical capabilities of ancient people. These “out-of-place artifacts” include artwork and legends reinterpreted to support extraterrestrial contact.

The idea is featured in fringe media, such as the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. The show mixes fact with fiction to promote theories of an alternate past, often incorporating white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents portray themselves as an oppressed minority of academics challenging mainstream archaeology, despite lacking credentials.

Like past archaeological endeavors, the focus is on monumental structures, suggesting that indigenous people could not have built them without alien help. However, some indigenous voices argue that ancient alien theory supports their stories of extraterrestrial origins.

A common theme is the portrayal of aliens as light-skinned or Aryan, as claimed by Erich von Däniken. Some proponents are associated with white supremacism.

Mainstream archaeologists have largely ignored these claims, while popular science explainers and skeptics have criticized them. Carl Sagan noted that cases of apparent interest have reasonable alternative explanations, misreporting, or are hoaxes and distortions.

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents 🔗

Paleocontact narratives appeared in early science fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and Erich von Däniken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von Däniken’s claims. By the early 1980s, support dwindled.

Shklovskii and Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe (1966) with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky. In Broca’s Brain (1979), Sagan expressed disapproval of writers like von Däniken who treated speculations as valid evidence of extraterrestrial contact. Sagan noted that many legends, artifacts, and out-of-place artifacts cited in support of ancient astronaut hypotheses could be explained with conventional hypotheses. He reiterated that extraterrestrial visits were possible but unproven and improbable.

Erich von Däniken 🔗

Erich von Däniken became a leading proponent in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his book Chariots of the Gods? (1968) and its sequels.

Von Däniken argued that certain artifacts required more advanced technology than was available to ancient cultures. He claimed that these artifacts were constructed by extraterrestrial visitors or humans who learned from them. Examples include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries.

He wrote that ancient art and iconography depict air and space vehicles, intelligent non-human creatures, ancient astronauts, and advanced technology. He also stated that geographically separated cultures share artistic themes, implying a common origin. One example is his interpretation of the sarcophagus lid from the tomb of Pacal the Great in Palenque, which he saw as a seated astronaut, while Maya texts identify it as a portrait of the ruler with the World Tree.

Von Däniken interpreted the origins of many religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, whose technology was seen as supernatural. He stated that religious traditions contain references to alien visitors, such as Ezekiel’s revelation, which he interpreted as a landing spacecraft.

His hypotheses became popularized in the U.S. through the NBC-TV documentary In Search of Ancient Astronauts and the film Chariots of the Gods.

Critics argue that von Däniken misrepresented data, made unfounded claims, and failed to validate his core claims. Christian creationists also criticized his work.

Regarding the Nazca Lines, von Däniken stated that they resembled an airfield when seen from the air. Kenneth L. Feder argues that readers seeing the Nazca Lines in a book about aliens would be more likely to associate them with extraterrestrial origins.

In 1970, von Däniken admitted that the Nazca markings could have been laid out using a system of coordinates.

Zecharia Sitchin 🔗

Zecharia Sitchin’s The Earth Chronicles series revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet Nibiru, which the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet” associated with the god Marduk. According to Sitchin, Nibiru orbits the Sun on a 3,600-year elongated orbit. Modern astronomy has found no evidence to support these ideas.

Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story of 50 Anunnaki from Nibiru who came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers, creating Homo sapiens sapiens: the “Adapa” or Adam of later mythology. Sitchin contended that the Anunnaki were active in human affairs until their culture was destroyed by global catastrophes caused by the end of the last ice age.

His work has not received mainstream scholarly support and has been criticized by professionals. Semitic languages scholar Michael S. Heiser says that many of Sitchin’s translations are inconsistent with Mesopotamian cuneiform dictionaries.

Alan F. Alford, author of Gods of the New Millennium, initially adhered to Sitchin’s hypotheses but later found fault, stating that the gods personified the falling sky and that the descent of the gods was a poetic rendition of the cataclysm myth.

Robert Temple 🔗

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He cites advanced astronomical knowledge, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations. His work draws on the studies of cultural anthropologists Marcel Griaule and Germaine Dieterlen.

His conclusions have been criticized by scientists, who point out discrepancies and suggest that the Dogon may have received their astronomical information recently from European sources.

UFO Religions 🔗

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, Raëlism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many see ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens. Psychologists have found that UFO religions have similarities suggesting that members associate enchantment with science fiction memes.

Claims of Proponents 🔗

The scientific consensus is that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is not impossible, but unjustified and unnecessary. The “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts. Since ancient astronauts are unnecessary, Occam’s razor should be applied and the hypothesis rejected.

Ancient Religious Texts 🔗

Proponents cite ancient mythologies, suggesting that creation myths of gods descending from the heavens to create or instruct humanity are representations of alien visitors. They draw an analogy to cargo cults, where isolated cultures believed Western ships and cargo were sent from the gods.

The ancient Sumerian myth of Enûma Eliš says humankind was created to serve gods called the “Annunaki.” Proponents believe that the Annunaki were aliens who came to Earth to mine gold and created the human race as slaves.

Ramayana 🔗

In Hindu mythology, the gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana. The Ramayana mentions these flying objects, used by the Lankan king Ravana from Sri Lanka.

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they are portrayed in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It includes a link to a separate article listing alleged extraterrestrial beings. A banner at the top indicates that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and needs more citations.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction, starting from antiquity and progressing through modern times.

Antiquity 🔗

This subsection covers early depictions of extraterrestrials, beginning with Lucian’s 2nd-century satire True History, where the protagonist visits the Moon and finds it inhabited by warring factions. It emphasizes how early concepts of extraterrestrials were tied to the development of astronomy and the understanding of celestial objects as physical entities. Early depictions often portrayed aliens as human-like, as exemplified by Voltaire’s Micromégas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac.

Early 20th Century 🔗

This section discusses the impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species on alien depictions, leading to the creation of non-humanoid aliens in fiction. Camille Flammarion’s works are mentioned as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also highlights H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds and The First Men in the Moon as influential works that explored the implications of evolution and alien civilizations. The rise of pulp magazines and their role in popularizing science fiction with various alien tropes are also discussed, including the common use of Martians, Venusians, and other Solar System inhabitants. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is noted for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times 🔗

This section covers the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. It mentions The Eternaut by Héctor Germán Oesterheld, an Argentine work that critiques imperialism and colonialism through an alien invasion of Buenos Aires. The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as a pivotal event that popularized the “grey alien” archetype. The influence of TV and films, particularly Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien, is highlighted, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budgetary constraints. The section concludes by mentioning the impact of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on creating more diverse and bizarre alien lifeforms.

Types 🔗

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It discusses differences in intelligence levels, biological forms (humanoid, Earth-species-like, or bizarre), and attitudes towards humanity (hostile, friendly, or indifferent). It also mentions that some extraterrestrials in fiction originate from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they appear in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It notes that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and encourages expansion with additional citations.

Extraterrestrials in Fiction 🔗

This section provides a general overview, defining an extraterrestrial (or alien) as a lifeform originating outside Earth. It highlights the prevalence of extraterrestrials as a theme in science fiction, with examples ranging from ancient works like Lucian of Samosata’s True History to modern depictions.

History 🔗

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction.

Antiquity 🔗

This subsection traces the earliest portrayals of extraterrestrials, starting with Lucian’s True History, which features a voyage to the Moon and a war between lunar and solar inhabitants. It explains how early concepts of aliens were tied to the development of astronomy and the initial tendency to imagine them as human-like. Voltaire’s Micromégas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac are mentioned as examples where extraterrestrials differed from humans only in culture or size.

The impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species is discussed, noting how it revolutionized alien depictions by inspiring authors to imagine non-humanoid lifeforms based on evolutionary principles. Camille Flammarion’s works and H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds are cited as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also acknowledges that many works of the era still featured human-like aliens.

The War of the Worlds is further analyzed for its exploration of Darwinian evolution, its depiction of Martians as apex predators, and its critique of British imperialism. It also introduced the tropes of alien invasion and extraterrestrials as monsters. Wells’ The First Men in the Moon is mentioned as an early attempt to detail an alien civilization, drawing parallels to ant colonies. Jules Verne’s contributions to science fiction and space exploration are also noted.

Early 20th Century 🔗

This section discusses the influence of pulp magazines on science fiction, highlighting the prevalence of quasi-human aliens, monstrous invaders, and the trope of human conquest of alien worlds. It mentions Ralph Milne Farley’s The Radio Man as an example. The section notes that most aliens in pulp magazines originated from planets or moons within the Solar System. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is recognized for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times 🔗

This section examines the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. The Eternaut by Héctor Germán Oesterheld is highlighted as a pioneering work of alien invasion set in Buenos Aires, serving as a critique of imperialism and the military dictatorship in Argentina.

The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as the first recorded claim of alien abduction, leading to the “grey alien” archetype. Steven Spielberg’s films Close Encounters of the Third Kind and E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial are mentioned as influential works that popularized the grey alien image.

The impact of television and film on alien portrayals is explored, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budget constraints, particularly in the Star Trek franchise. Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien are mentioned as franchises that sustained public interest in outer space.

The section concludes by discussing the influence of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on alien depictions, allowing for more bizarre and imaginative lifeforms.

Types 🔗

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It discusses variations in intelligence, biological aspects (humanoid, Earth-species-like, or weird), and attitudes towards humanity (hostile, friendly, or indifferent). It also mentions the possibility of extraterrestrials originating from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion 🔗

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins 🔗

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations 🔗

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration 🔗

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion 🔗

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans 🔗

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility 🔗

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

See also 🔗

This section provides a list of related topics, including interplanetary contamination, potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact, space colonization, UFO religion, The Kraken Wakes, list of films featuring space stations, and the Wow! signal.

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article, providing sources for the information presented.

item.title: UFO Abduction (film)
item.description:
UFO Abduction (film) 🔗

This article provides information about the 1989 American found-footage science fiction horror film UFO Abduction, also known as The McPherson Tape. It details the film’s production, plot, cast, release, reception, and legacy, as well as its remake.

Title Misconception 🔗

This section clarifies that the film, originally conceived as UFO Abduction, is now more commonly known as The McPherson Tape.

Plot 🔗

This section outlines the film’s storyline, which centers on the Van Heese family in Connecticut during a birthday celebration on October 8, 1983. The family encounters extraterrestrials, leading to a night of terror and a supposed alien abduction. Key events include the initial sighting of a spacecraft, attempts by the aliens to enter the house, the shooting of an alien, and the family’s eventual disappearance. The film is presented as found footage, with the implication that the Van Heeses’ whereabouts remain unknown.

Cast 🔗

This section lists the actors who portrayed the Van Heese family members and the aliens. Key actors include Tommy Giavocchini, Patrick Kelley, Shirly McCalla, Stacey Shulman, Christine Staples, Laura Tomas, and Dean Alioto.

Production 🔗

This section details the film’s production, noting that it was written, directed, filmed, and produced by Dean Alioto through IndieSyndicate Productions. It highlights the film’s low budget of $6,500 and its presentation as found footage.

Release, Reception and Legacy 🔗

This section discusses the film’s limited release through Axiom Films and its intended appearance as a genuine 1983 home video recording. It mentions the destruction of the film’s materials in a warehouse fire, hindering its wide release. It also notes criticisms of the original film’s sound quality, visual effects, and aesthetics. The section further mentions the film’s official DVD and Digital download release in 2018 and its Blu-ray re-release in 2020 by AGFA, including a new transfer and director’s commentary.

Remake 🔗

This section mentions the 1998 remake of UFO Abduction by Dean Alioto and Paul Chitlik, which had a larger budget and professional actors. The remake was originally titled The McPherson Tape but was later changed to Alien Abduction: Incident in Lake County.

See also 🔗

This section provides links to related topics, including the Kelly–Hopkinsville encounter and UFO conspiracy theories.

item.title: UFO (1956 film)
item.description:
UFO (1956 film) 🔗

A 1956 American semi-documentary film that explores the development of the UFO phenomenon in the United States. It is noted for its use of documentary clips that have been featured in other UFO-related media.

Origins and plot 🔗

In 1952, Hollywood producer Clarence Greene, after witnessing an unusual aerial object, contacted US Air Force public information officer Albert M. Chop. Intrigued, Greene decided to create a documentary about UFOs, using film footage provided by Chop. The film begins in 1947, covering early UFO sightings like the Kenneth Arnold sighting, the Mantell UFO incident, and the Gorman Dogfight. It follows the evolution of UFOs as a cultural fad and a concern for the US Air Force, including the history of Project Sign. The film then focuses on Albert M. Chop, who is assigned as the public information officer at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio. Chop initially debunks UFOs but gradually changes his views, believing they are unknown aircraft, possibly extraterrestrial. By 1952, Chop is in Washington, D.C., as the press spokesman for Project Blue Book. The documentary analyzes the Mariana UFO Incident of 1950 and the 1952 UFO film taken near the Great Salt Lake in Utah by Delbert Newhouse. The film concludes with the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident, where Chop played a central role, ultimately stating his belief that UFOs are a real, physical phenomenon of unknown origin.

Cast 🔗

The cast includes Willis Sperry, Nicholas Mariana, Delbert Newhouse, Wendell Swanson, and U.S. Air Force General John A. Samford as themselves. Tom Towers plays Albert M. (Al) Chop, Floyd Burton plays Major Dewey Fournet, Gene Coughlan plays an editor from the Dayton Daily News, Bert Freed plays a Colonel, Stan Gordon plays a reporter, Marie Kenna plays Mrs. Albert Chop, Harry Morgan provides voices, Robert Phillips plays Captain Edward Ruppelt, William Solomon plays a German scientist, and Olan Soule is a narrator.

Trivia 🔗

Actor Harry Morgan, known for his roles in M*A*S*H and Dragnet 1967, voices the pilot of “Air Force 216” and “Red Dog One” during key scenes, including the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident. Morgan’s Dragnet 1967 co-star Jack Webb produced and narrated the 1978 television series Project U.F.O., which recreated Project Bluebook.

See also 🔗

Lists similar media, including the book The Report On Unidentified Flying Objects (1956), the film UFOs: Past, Present, and Future (1976), and the TV broadcast UFO Cover Up? Live (1988).

References 🔗

Lists the references used in the article, including articles from the Los Angeles Times, Turner Classic Movies, Christian Science Monitor, The Washington Post and Times-Herald, and New York Times.

External links 🔗

Provides links to the film’s IMDb page, TCM Movie Database page, and a full film available at the Internet Archive.

item.title: Alien Trespass (2009 Film)
item.description:
Alien Trespass (2009 Film) 🔗

This is a description of the 2009 film Alien Trespass, directed by R.W. Goodwin. The film is a science-fiction comedy that pays homage to the B movies of the 1950s.

Plot 🔗

The story is set in 1957 in California’s Mojave Desert. Astronomer Ted Lewis and his wife Lana are observing a meteor shower when something crashes nearby. Ted investigates and discovers an alien spaceship. His body is then taken over by Urp, a well-meaning alien who is searching for Ghota, a one-eyed monster that escaped from the ship. Ghota consumes people to grow and multiply, threatening Earth. Urp enlists the help of Tammy, a local waitress, to stop Ghota. The local police, Chief Dawson and Officer Vern, are skeptical. Urp and Tammy hunt down Ghota, and they eventually fall in love. At the end, Urp returns to his home planet, leaving Tammy to pursue her dreams.

Cast 🔗

The film stars Eric McCormack as Ted Lewis/Urp, Jenni Baird as Tammy, Robert Patrick as Vernon, Jody Thompson as Lana Lewis, and Dan Lauria as Chief Dawson. Other cast members include Sarah Smyth, Aaron Brooks, Andrew Dunbar, Dayna Reid, Chelah Horsdal, Sage Brocklebank, Jonathon Young, and Tom McBeath.

Analysis 🔗

The film replicates the look and feel of 1950s science fiction films, with the exception of being in color. The film uses the trope of monsters terrorizing small desert towns, which was common in 1950s B movies due to lower production costs. The character of Lana Lewis is depicted as a “sexpot,” a common archetype in 1950s science fiction films. The Ghota is similar to B.O.B. from Monsters vs. Aliens. The romance between Urp and Tammy is reminiscent of The Day the Earth Stood Still. Director Goodwin states that the film takes elements from The Day the Earth Stood Still, It Came from Outer Space, and The War of the Worlds.

Reception 🔗

The film received mixed reviews. Rotten Tomatoes gives it a 38% approval rating, with the consensus being that it loses its charm due to tedious dialogue and cheesy special effects. Roger Ebert gave the film two out of four stars, stating that it was a labor of love but questioning whether there was a demand for cheesy 1950s sci-fi movies. Jeannette Catsoulis of The New York Times described the film as a charming but pointless homage. Betsy Sharkey of the Los Angeles Times felt that the film stayed too true to the era and genre, forgetting to entertain. IGN praised the film’s recreation of the 1950s aesthetic but found that it couldn’t decide whether to emulate or satirize the genre. Ty Burr of The Boston Globe felt that the film was superior to Monsters vs. Aliens. Entertainment Weekly gave the film a “B+” rating, praising its warm tone and anti-CGI look. Gary Westfahl considers the film an overlooked gem that captures the charm of 1950s science fiction films.

See also 🔗

The article lists other films related to the genre, including Earth vs. the Flying Saucers, Forbidden Planet, Invaders from Mars, Mars Attacks!, and The Lost Skeleton of Cadavra.

Sources 🔗

The article cites several sources, including reviews by Roger Ebert, Gary Westfahl, and articles from AMC.com.

References 🔗

The article includes a list of references to support the information presented.

External links 🔗

The article provides links to the film’s official website, IMDb page, Rotten Tomatoes page, TCM Movie Database page, and articles from The New York Times, AMCtv.com, and Starlog magazine.
