item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis 🔗

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term 🔗

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature back to the mid-1960s. Key figures mentioned include French ufologist Jacques Vallée, who used the term in his 1966 book, and French engineer Aimé Michel. James E. McDonald and James Harder also used the term in 1968 during a symposium and congressional testimony. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in the Condon Report (1969). Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology 🔗

This section explores the historical context of the ETH, tracing its origins to earlier concepts such as Percival Lowell’s ideas about Martian canals and civilizations, the science fiction writings of H.G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century. The modern ETH took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience, popular culture, and unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups like NICAP and APRO.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits 🔗

This section presents early examples of speculation about extraterrestrial visitors, including an 1864 French newspaper story about the discovery of an alien-like creature. It discusses H.G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” and the “mystery airships” reported in the late 19th century. Mentions comic strips and radio/movie serials like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon, which popularized the idea of alien visitation. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” is also noted for causing public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America 🔗

This section focuses on the surge of UFO sightings in 1947, beginning with Kenneth Arnold’s report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier. It notes that Arnold considered the possibility of extraterrestrial origins and that the ETH was discussed in newspapers and letters to the editor. Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet is mentioned, as is R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that the saucers could be vehicles from Mars or other planets. The section also references Charles Fort’s earlier documentation of unidentified flying objects.

Evolution of Public Opinion 🔗

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions movies from the 1950s depicting flying saucers and aliens, such as “The Day the Earth Stood Still” and “The War of the Worlds.” A 1951 Popular Science poll indicated that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen man-made aircraft, while a small percentage believed they had seen alien craft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A 2002 Roper poll reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion 🔗

This section briefly mentions the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA 🔗

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP using scientific methods and an agnostic approach. Kopparapu presented a paper in August 2021 supporting the ETH.

Private or Government Studies 🔗

This section highlights private and government studies that have supported the ETH or had members who disagreed with official conclusions. Examples include a 1948 USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins, and the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for unexplained cases. It also mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. The CIA’s internal scientific review and the views of individuals within Project Blue Book, such as Major Dewey Fournet and Edward J. Ruppelt, are discussed. Statements by CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter and Greek physicist Paul Santorini are also included. The section further mentions the COMETA report (1999) and the views of Jean-Jacques Velasco, head of the French UFO investigation SEPRA, and Yves Sillard, head of GEIPAN.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH 🔗

This section presents critical responses to the ETH, noting that there is no scientific proof to back up claims of alien encounters. It states that no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery 🔗

This section discusses the U.S. military’s involvement in investigating UFOs, including the formation of Project Sign in 1947. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also mentions the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which recommended a policy of public debunkery to reduce the number of UFO reports.

Involvement of Scientists 🔗

This section highlights the scientific community’s skepticism towards the ETH. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism and quotes Carl Sagan’s statement about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation. Peter A. Sturrock’s call for examining other possible theories is also included. The section presents results from Sturrock’s polls of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics and American Astronomical Society members, showing limited support for the ETH. It summarizes J. Allen Hynek’s seven key reasons for not accepting the ETH, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology 🔗

This section notes that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, which has challenged the claimed phenomenology of UFOs and caused a crisis of confidence among some UFO researchers.

NASA 🔗

This section states NASA’s official position as of 2006, which is that the ETH lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits.

CIA 🔗

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the Robertson Panel in 1953 to debunk data collected by Project Blue Book.

Official White House Position 🔗

This section presents the White House’s official response in November 2011 to petitions asking the U.S. government to acknowledge alien visits and disclose any withholding of government interactions with extraterrestrial beings. The response states that the U.S. government has no evidence of life outside our planet or that an extraterrestrial presence has contacted or engaged any member of the human race.

Counter Critique of the Official Position: Conspiracy Theories 🔗

This section discusses the concept of a conspiracy of silence or official cover-up to suppress information about UFOs. It mentions James Harder’s argument in 1968 that significant evidence existed to prove UFOs but had been suppressed. A 1971 survey showed that more Americans believed the government was concealing information about UFOs than believed in the existence of UFOs or the ETH itself. Comments from former NASA astronauts Gordon Cooper and Brian O’Leary about NASA and the government suppressing UFO sightings are also included.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_UFO_hypothesis

item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis 🔗

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term 🔗

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature. It notes that the term gained traction in the latter half of the 1960s, with early usage attributed to French ufologist Jacques Vallée in his 1966 book. Other figures who used the term in the late 1960s include Aimé Michel, James E. McDonald, and James Harder. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in 1969 when presenting the findings of the Condon Report. Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology 🔗

This section explores the historical context leading up to the modern ETH. It traces the origins of the idea of extraterrestrial life and visitation to earlier concepts, including Percival Lowell’s theories about Martian canals and ancient Martian civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH, linking unidentified aircraft to alien life, took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits 🔗

This section presents examples of early speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a French newspaper story from 1864 about the discovery of an alien-like creature inside an egg-shaped structure. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” (1898), which popularized the idea of Martian visitation and invasion. The section notes a surge in “mystery airship” reports in the late 19th century, with some speculating about Martian origins. It also mentions the influence of comic strips, radio shows, and movies like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon in popularizing the idea of alien visitation in spaceships. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” caused some public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America 🔗

This section focuses on the events surrounding the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947 and the subsequent “flying saucer” craze. It details Arnold’s initial report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier and his consideration of the possibility of extraterrestrial origins. The section notes the widespread speculation in newspapers about the nature of the “saucers,” including theories about secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria. It mentions Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet and R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The section also cites journalist Edward R. Murrow’s observation that the ETH did not gain widespread attention until about 18 months after Arnold’s sighting.

Evolution of Public Opinion 🔗

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of the first U.S. poll of public UFO perceptions by Gallup in August 1947, which showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation for the sightings. The section also discusses the influence of movies depicting flying saucers and aliens in the early 1950s. It cites a poll published in Popular Science magazine in 1951, which reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion 🔗

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA 🔗

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP with an agnostic approach, involving experts from various fields to collect data and deduce the identity of such UAP. In August 2021, Kopparapu presented a paper supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies 🔗

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or have had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 Top Secret USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for the most perplexing unexplained cases. The section mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the CIA’s internal scientific review of UFOs in the early 1950s, noting that some CIA scientists were seriously considering the ETH. The section mentions extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book, including Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who later became a staunch supporter of the ETH. It also cites statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who urged Congressional action to reduce the dangers from secrecy about unidentified flying objects. The section mentions Greek physicist Paul Santorini’s claim that a 1947 Greek government investigation into the European Ghost rockets concluded that they were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the 1968 Condon Report, noting that many members of the study disagreed with Condon’s methods and biases. The section mentions the 1999 private French COMETA report, which concluded that the hypothesis of extraterrestrial visitors best accounted for the facts. It also discusses Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, who stated that 14% of the cases studied by SEPRA were ‘utterly inexplicable and extraterrestrial’ in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH 🔗

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It notes that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien encounters. It states that despite ardent believers, no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that various UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery 🔗

This section discusses the U.S. military’s investigation of UFOs and its efforts to debunk the ETH. It mentions the formation of Project Sign in 1947, the first official U.S. military UFO study. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also discusses the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which was organized in 1953 to review the Blue Book’s best evidence and recommend an official policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists 🔗

This section examines the scientific community’s response to the ETH. It notes that the scientific community has shown very little support for the ETH, largely accepting the explanation that UFO reports are the result of misinterpretations or hoaxes. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism about the ETH. The section cites Carl Sagan’s observation about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s statement about the narrow polarization of the UFO debate around the ETH. The section presents the results of a 1973 poll of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics members, which found that about 10% believed that UFOs were vehicles from outer space. It also presents the results of a 1977 poll of American Astronomical Society members, which asked them to assign probabilities to eight possible explanations for UFOs. The section summarizes the primary scientific arguments against ETH, as outlined by J. Allen Hynek, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon in time and space, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology 🔗

This section discusses the argument that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, calling into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA 🔗

This section presents NASA’s official standpoint on the ETH, which is that it lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits and that no claims of UFOs as being alien craft have any validity.

CIA 🔗

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

Official White 🔗

item.title: Alien Nation Comic Books
item.description:
Alien Nation Comic Books 🔗

This article details the comic book adaptations and spin-offs based on the Alien Nation franchise, which originated with the 1988 film. DC Comics initially published a single-issue adaptation of the film, followed by a series of spin-off titles by Malibu Comics under their Adventure Comics imprint from 1990 to 1992.

Publications 🔗

This section provides a table listing all the Alien Nation comic book titles, their creators, publisher, number of issues, publication dates, and additional notes.

  • Alien Nation (DC Comics): A one-shot comic written by Martin Pasko with art by Jerry Bingham, adapting the original film written by Rockne S. O’Bannon. It was released in December 1988.

  • Alien Nation: The Spartans: A 4-issue mini-series published by Adventure Comics (Malibu Comics imprint) from July to November 1990. It was written by Bill Spangler with art by James Tucker and was also released as a trade paperback. The story involves Ruth Lawrence of the Newcomer Advocacy League investigating the disappearance of Art Deco, the brother of Newcomer Harvey Wallbanger.

  • Alien Nation: A Breed Apart: A 4-issue mini-series published by Adventure Comics (Malibu Comics imprint) from November 1990 to March 1991. It was written by Steve Jones with art by Stan Timmons and Jimmy Palmiotti. The story follows LAPD detectives Wayne Hadenfelt and Log B’Omen as they investigate a home invasion that appears to be a gangland assassination. The mini-series ended on an unresolved cliffhanger.

  • Alien Nation: The Skin Trade: A 4-issue mini-series published by Adventure Comics (Malibu Comics imprint) from March to June 1991. It was written by Lowell Cunningham with art by Leonard Kirk.

  • Ape Nation: A 4-issue mini-series published by Adventure Comics (Malibu Comics imprint) from February to June 1991. It was written by Charles Marshall with art by M.C. Wyman. This series is a crossover with Planet of the Apes.

  • Alien Nation: The Firstcomers: A 4-issue mini-series published by Adventure Comics (Malibu Comics imprint) from May to August 1991. It was written by Martin Powell with art by Tim Eldred.

  • Alien Nation: The Public Enemy: A 4-issue mini-series published by Adventure Comics (Malibu Comics imprint) from December 1991 to March 1991. It was written by Lowell Cunningham with art by Sandy Carruthers.

  • Alien Nation Television Special: The Lost Episode: A one-shot comic published by Malibu Graphics in 1992. It was written by Bill Spangler with art by Terry Pallot. The comic is based on “Soul Train,” a script from the unproduced second season of the Alien Nation TV series, written by Diane Frolov and Andrew Schneider. The premise and elements of this script were later used in the Alien Nation: Dark Horizon TV movie.

See also 🔗

This section contains a link to the “List of comics based on films” Wikipedia page.

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article, including “Batman Unmasked: Analyzing a Cultural Icon” by Will Brooker (2001).

External links 🔗

This section provides an external link to “Welcome Back to the Planet of the Apes,” an article from Comics Scene #13 (1990) about the Adventure Comics run on Planet of the Apes, including Ape Nation.

item.title: Extraterrestrial (2014 film)
item.description:
Extraterrestrial (2014 film) 🔗

A 2014 Canadian science fiction horror film directed by Colin Minihan, one half of The Vicious Brothers, who also co-produced, wrote, and edited the film. The film stars Brittany Allen, Freddie Stroma, and Melanie Papalia as a group of friends who must defend themselves against an alien onslaught.

Plot 🔗

April and her boyfriend Kyle, along with friends Seth, Melanie, and Lex, head to April’s parents’ cabin for the weekend. After a series of events including a traffic stop and some recreational drug use, they witness a UFO crash in the woods. Investigating, they discover an alien spacecraft and footprints. The group encounters an alien, which they shoot. After this, the group is hunted by aliens, and they seek help from Travis, a family friend of April’s, who explains the government’s alleged treaty with the aliens. The friends try to survive the night as they are picked off one by one. The survivors are eventually abducted and experimented on. Kyle and April are returned to Earth, only to be killed by U.S. Army soldiers who are cleaning up the crash site, covering up the existence of extraterrestrials.

Cast 🔗

The film stars Brittany Allen as April, Freddie Stroma as Kyle, and Melanie Papalia as Melanie. Other notable cast members include Jesse Moss as Seth, Anja Savcic as Lex, Gil Bellows as Sheriff Murphy, and Michael Ironside as Travis. Sean Rogerson plays Deputy Mitchell, Emily Perkins plays Nancy McPherson, and Jacob Tremblay has an uncredited role as Matty.

Release 🔗

Extraterrestrial premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival on April 18, 2014, under the IFC Midnight banner. The Scream Factory later released the film on Blu-ray and DVD on May 12.

Reception 🔗

Critical reception for Extraterrestrial has been predominantly negative. Reviewers criticized the film for relying too heavily on familiar tropes and clichés of sci-fi horror movies. Some reviewers praised the film’s visuals, but overall, the film received poor reviews. Rotten Tomatoes reports an aggregate score of 28%, with the consensus being that the film delivers some gory thrills but is weighed down by clichés.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_(2014_film)

item.title: Phil the Alien (2004 Film)
item.description:
Phil the Alien (2004 Film) 🔗

This entry provides information about the 2004 Canadian comedy film Phil the Alien.

Overview 🔗

Phil the Alien is a Canadian comedy film released in 2004. It was written and directed by Rob Stefaniuk, who also stars in the titular role. The film features a blend of science fiction and comedy elements.

Plot Summary 🔗

The plot revolves around Phil, an extraterrestrial with shape-shifting and telekinetic abilities, who crash-lands in Northern Ontario. He befriends a local child, his father, and a talking beaver. Phil adopts the persona of a stereotypical Canadian small-town alcoholic while hiding from a military general. His telekinetic powers lead some to believe he is the Christian messiah, and he joins a local rock band. A Quebecois assassin attempts to kill him while he’s on tour with the band. The ending involves suspense, treachery, and dolphins.

Cast 🔗

The film stars:

  • Rob Stefaniuk as Phil the Alien
  • Nicole de Boer as Madame Madame
  • Graham Greene as Wolf
  • Boyd Banks as Slim
  • Christopher Barry as Thomas

References 🔗

The article cites two references:

  1. A Sudbury Star article from September 24, 2004, titled “‘When a spaceship crashes in Northern Ontario, it’s funny’”.
  2. A CityNews Toronto article from April 2, 2024, reporting the death of Joe Flaherty, noting this film as his final role.

The article provides a link to the film’s IMDb page.

item.title: Trinity UFO Case
item.description:
Trinity UFO Case 🔗

This article discusses the alleged Trinity UFO case, a story about a crashed unidentified object near the Trinity test site in New Mexico in August 1945. The narrative centers around claims made by José Padilla and Remigio Baca, who, as young boys, reported witnessing the crash and its aftermath.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Trinity UFO case by referencing the broader history of UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting, the 1947 flying disc craze, the Roswell incident, and the Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax. It also introduces Jacques Vallée, a ufologist and author who publicized the Trinity case, noting his involvement in the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

The Context 🔗

This section describes the setting of the alleged incident, focusing on the Padilla family’s ranch near the Trinity test site. It details the family’s lifestyle, including Faustino Padilla’s work and José’s responsibilities on the ranch. It also mentions the impact of the Trinity test on the local population, including Inez Padilla’s loss of eyesight. The section touches on the backgrounds of both the Padilla and Baca families, noting their Spanish and Apache heritage.

Claims by Padilla and Baca 🔗

This section outlines the specific claims made by José Padilla and Remigio Baca regarding their alleged encounter with a crashed UFO.

First day 🔗

This subsection details the initial sighting of the crashed object by Padilla and Baca on August 16, 1945. It describes their search for a lost cow, the loud bang they heard, and their discovery of a groove in the ground leading to an “avocado-shaped” object. They report seeing small, insect-like creatures near the object, which they compared to a praying mantis, Jerusalem cricket, and fire ant. The boys estimated the object’s size and described its metallic appearance, as well as the appearance of the creatures.

Third day 🔗

This subsection recounts the boys’ return to the crash site with José Padilla’s father, Faustino Padilla, and Eddie Apodaca, a state police officer. It states that the adults entered the object but were visibly disturbed afterward, warning the boys to remain silent. The boys later returned alone and witnessed soldiers collecting debris.

Fourth day 🔗

This subsection describes a visit to the Padilla family by Sergeant R. Avila, who requested permission to access the property to recover an “experimental weather balloon.” Avila emphasized the need for secrecy and the use of heavy equipment.

The fifth and the following days 🔗

This subsection details the alleged military operation to recover the crashed object. It describes the construction of a road and gate, the arrival of a lowboy trailer, and the use of a crane to lift the object. Padilla and Baca claim to have secretly observed the military’s activities. They also describe how they obtained a “souvenir” from inside the object, a metal piece they named “Tesoro.”

After the recovery 🔗

This section describes the aftermath of the alleged recovery operation. It mentions the removal of the object, the clearing of the crash site, and the hiding of the “Tesoro” by the boys. It also touches on the atmosphere of secrecy and fear in the area, with rumors of government intervention for those who spoke too much about the events. Vallée draws parallels between this case and the Roswell incident.

Publication 🔗

This section details the publication history of the Trinity UFO case. It mentions Ben Moffett’s initial reporting in 2003, the analysis of the “Tesoro” metal piece, Timothy Good’s mention of the incident in his book, and Paola Harris’s awareness of the case.

Criticisms and responses 🔗

This section presents criticisms of the Trinity UFO case, primarily from skeptical writer Brian Dunning, who characterizes the story as a hoax. Dunning cites inconsistencies in the story, such as the claim that Eddie Apodaca was a state trooper at the time of the incident, when he was actually serving in World War II. It also includes responses from Jacques Vallée, who defends the case and addresses the criticisms raised by Douglas Dean Johnson. Vallée acknowledges some inaccuracies in the original reporting but maintains that the core story is valid.

See also 🔗

This section lists related topics, specifically the Roswell incident and the Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax.

Bibliography 🔗

This section lists the books cited in the article, including Need to Know by Timothy Good and Trinity: The Best-Kept Secret by Jacques Vallée and Paola L. Harris.

References 🔗

This section provides a list of citations used in the article.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_UFO_Case

item.title: Ariel School UFO incident
item.description:
1994 Sighting in Zimbabwe 🔗

On September 16, 1994, a UFO sighting occurred outside Ruwa, Zimbabwe, witnessed by 62 pupils aged six to twelve at Ariel School. The children reported seeing silver crafts descend from the sky and land in a nearby field. Some claimed to have encountered creatures dressed in black who communicated a telepathic message with an environmental theme, causing fear and distress.

Fortean writer Jerome Clark called it the “most remarkable close encounter of the third kind of the 1990s.” Skeptics have suggested mass hysteria as a possible explanation. Some children maintain the truthfulness of their accounts.

Background 🔗

Ruwa is described as a small agricultural center 22 kilometers southeast of Harare. Ariel School was a private school, primarily attended by children from wealthy white families in Harare.

Two days before the Ariel School incident, numerous UFO sightings were reported throughout southern Africa, including reports of a bright fireball in the sky at night. This led to a wave of UFO mania in Zimbabwe. Brian Dunning suggests the fireball was the re-entry of the Zenit-2 rocket from the Cosmos 2290 satellite launch. Local UFO researcher Cynthia Hind recorded other alien sightings during this period.

Incident 🔗

The sightings at Ariel School occurred at 10 a.m. on September 16, 1994, during mid-morning break. The faculty was in a meeting at the time. The incident lasted about fifteen minutes. The children reported the event to their teachers, but were dismissed.

After telling their parents, many parents came to the school the next day to discuss the incident with the faculty. The sighting was reported on ZBC Radio, where Cynthia Hind learned about it.

BBC correspondent Tim Leach visited the school on September 19 to film interviews with pupils and staff. Hind visited the school on September 20, interviewing children and asking them to draw what they had seen. She reported that the children told her the same story.

In November, Harvard University professor of psychiatry John Mack visited the school to interview witnesses. Mack had investigated UFO sightings and the alien abduction phenomenon throughout the 1990s.

According to interviews by Hind, Leach, and Mack, 62 children reported seeing at least one UFO. Silver objects, usually described as discs, appeared in the sky and descended to a field near the school.

Between one and four creatures with big eyes and dressed in black exited a craft and approached the children. Some children ran, but others stayed and watched. Mack’s interviews suggest the creatures telepathically communicated an environmental message to the children before returning to the craft and flying away. Dunning notes that the telepathic message aspect was primarily in Mack’s reports, although Hind reported it later.

Children described being warned about impending events and the importance of avoiding pollution. One child said they were told the world would end because of a lack of care for the planet.

The children insisted they had not seen a plane. Hind noted that the children’s different cultural backgrounds led to varying interpretations, with some believing they had seen tikoloshes from Shona and Ndebele folklore rather than extraterrestrials.

Aftermath 🔗

The Ariel School UFO incident became a famous UFO case in Africa. A June 2021 episode of the BBC’s Witness History described it as “one of the most significant events in UFO history.” Ufologists continue to cite the case as evidence of extraterrestrial visits to Earth. Skeptics have suggested mass hysteria or a prank as explanations. Gideon Reid proposed a hypothesis involving confusion with touring puppet shows promoting AIDS awareness. Another argument suggests the children misidentified a dust devil.

Hind interviewed the children in groups, potentially leading to cross-contamination of their stories. Dunning says that Mack, interviewed the children two months after the alleged sighting and as a known environmentalist, “prompted and suggested” the telepathic communication angle, which was not present in Hind’s previous report.

Several witnesses maintain the truthfulness of their accounts. In 2014, a witness told the Mail & Guardian that she fears the creatures will return and that she can sense when they are back in the atmosphere. In 2016, witness Emily Trim exhibited paintings described as a “manifestation of the messages she received” from the beings. In June 2021, Barstool Sports writer Zah, a former Ariel School pupil, recounted seeing a bright light and aliens exiting it. Other witnesses were interviewed for the 2020 documentary The Phenomenon.

In the 2023 Netflix documentary “Encounters”, a former student named Dallyn claimed that he was behind this incident. He claimed that he purposefully told his classmates and other students that a “shiny rock” in the distance was a UFO. According to his own statement in the documentary, he never thought this would work, and was surprised about the mass hysteria. Dallyn’s claims in the documentary directly contradict claims made on camera 15 years prior to the documentary, describing the UFO as having a light that would “flash a different color in the sky.”

See also 🔗

  • List of reported UFO sightings
  • Westall UFO, a similar UFO sighting by school students

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_School_UFO_incident

item.title: Alien Autopsy (2006 film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy (2006 film) 🔗

A 2006 British comedy film directed by Jonny Campbell and written by William Davies, Alien Autopsy is a fictionalized account of the events surrounding the infamous “alien autopsy” film promoted by Ray Santilli. The film stars Ant & Dec as Santilli and Gary Shoefield.

Plot 🔗

Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield recount their story to a documentary maker. In 1995, they travel to the United States to find Elvis memorabilia. They encounter Harvey, a former US Army cameraman, who offers them a film from 1947 depicting the autopsy of an alien from the Roswell UFO crash.

After returning to England, Ray and Gary discover the film has degraded. To avoid repercussions from their investor, Laszlo Voros, they decide to recreate the autopsy film. They use a mannequin and meat products to create a replica alien and film it in Gary’s sister’s living room.

They sell the film, earning a large sum of money. Voros demands a larger share of the profits but is killed in a mysterious accident. Ray and Gary travel to Argentina to promote the film, where they are followed by reporter Amber Fuentes. They produce a fake interview with a homeless man posing as Harvey to maintain Harvey’s anonymity.

Ray and Gary attempt to restore the original 1947 footage, but after viewing the results, they decide to bury the film.

Cast 🔗

The film stars Declan Donnelly as Ray Santilli and Anthony McPartlin as Gary Shoefield. Bill Pullman plays Morgan Banner, the documentary maker. Götz Otto portrays Laszlo Voros, and Harry Dean Stanton plays Harvey. Other cast members include Morwenna Banks, Omid Djalili, Jimmy Carr, and Jonathan Frakes as himself.

Reception 🔗

The film received mainly positive reviews, earning a 75% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Releases 🔗

The film was released as a Region 2 DVD by Warner Home Video on July 3, 2006. In America, it was released as a Region 1 DVD by Warner Home Video on September 21, 2010.

Soundtrack 🔗

The film’s soundtrack includes songs by Supergrass, Pete Moore, The Beloved, Stakka Bo, The Monkees, Stereo MC’s, Tom Jones, Nouvelle Vague, Son of Dork, and Babylon Zoo.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(2006_film)

item.title: Alien from L.A. (1988 Film)
item.description:
Alien from L.A. (1988 Film) 🔗

This is a description of the 1988 science fiction film Alien from L.A. directed by Albert Pyun, based on the provided Wikipedia article.

Overview 🔗

Alien from L.A. is a 1988 science fiction film directed by Albert Pyun, starring Kathy Ireland. The film centers on a young woman from Los Angeles who discovers an underground civilization in Atlantis. The film is loosely based on Jules Verne’s Journey to the Center of the Earth. It was also featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000.

Plot 🔗

Wanda Saknussemm, a social misfit from Los Angeles, learns of her archaeologist father’s death in North Africa. While sorting through his belongings, she discovers notes about Atlantis, an alien ship that crashed and sank into the Earth’s center. Wanda accidentally falls into a deep hole and awakens in the underground world of Atlantis. She encounters Gus, a miner, who helps her search for her father, whom she believes is still alive. The Atlanteans consider surface dwellers “aliens” and suspect Wanda and her father of planning an invasion. Wanda becomes a fugitive, pursued by “Government House” and the crime lord Mambino. She receives assistance from Charmin’, a rogue who falls in love with her. Eventually, Wanda is captured by General Rykov, who intends to kill her and her father. Gus helps them escape, and they return to the surface. The film concludes with Wanda rejecting her ex-boyfriend and reuniting with Charmin’ on a beach.

Cast 🔗

The film stars:

  • Kathy Ireland as Wanda Saknussemm
  • William R. Moses as Guten “Gus” Edway
  • Richard Haines as Professor Arnold Saknussemm
  • Don Michael Paul as Robbie
  • Thom Mathews as “Charmin'”
  • Janie Du Plessis as General Rykov / Shank / Claims Officer
  • Simon Poland as Consul Triton Crassus / The Mailman
  • Linda Kerridge as Roryis Freki / Auntie Pearl
  • Kristen Trucksess as Stacy
  • Lochner de Kock as Professor Ovid Galba / Paddy Mahoney
  • Deep Roy as Mambino, The Boss of Bosses

Production 🔗

Albert Pyun took on Alien from L.A. after being approached by producers Yoram Globus and Menahem Golan during the troubled production of Journey to the Center of the Earth. Pyun agreed to finish the film if he could also film Alien from L.A. for under $1 million. Kathy Ireland was cast by Pyun after seeing a photo of her. Filming locations included Los Angeles, Redondo Beach, South Africa, and Namibia. The gold mines and dumps around South Africa were used for the underground setpieces. The sets were inspired by “future noir” films like Alien and Blade Runner.

Release 🔗

Alien from L.A. was released on February 26, 1988. It was released on VHS in June 1995 and on DVD in June 2005. Vinegar Syndrome has released a Blu-ray edition with special features. A direct-to-video sequel, Journey to the Center of the Earth, also directed by Albert Pyun and starring Kathy Ireland, was released in 1989.

Reception 🔗

Joe Bob Briggs called it a “pretty decent film”, awarding it two stars. Rebecca Harris of the Abilene Reporter-News gave the film 2.5 stars out of 4. David Picking called it “a cheapo adventure movie without a single redeeming quality”. Rob Thomas of The Capital Times said “Completely awful – you can’t believe they’re serious.” Daniel M. Kimmel of the Worcester Telegram & Gazette gave the film one out of five stars.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_from_L.A.

item.title: The Alien Factor (1978 film)
item.description:
The Alien Factor (1978 film) 🔗

This is a description of the 1978 science fiction horror film The Alien Factor, directed, written, and produced by Don Dohler.

Plot 🔗

The plot centers around a spaceship crash in a sparsely populated area of Earth. Three grotesque aliens survive the crash and begin terrorizing the local residents. A character named Ben Zachary steps forward to fight back against the extraterrestrial threat.

Cast 🔗

The main cast includes:

  • Don Leifert as Ben Zachary
  • Tom Griffith as Sheriff Cinder
  • Richard Dyszel as Mayor Wicker
  • Mary Mertens as Edie Martin
  • Richard Geiwitz as Pete
  • George Stover as Steven
  • Eleanor Herman as Mary Jane Carter
  • Anne Frith as Dr. Ruth Sherman

Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino played the aliens Inferbyce and Zagatile, respectively.

Production 🔗

The Alien Factor marked Don Dohler’s directorial debut after he was laid off from his job as a payroll manager. The initial script was a comedy with 15 monsters, but it was changed to a straight horror film with only three monsters. Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino built the creature suits for the Inferbyce and Zagtile, respectively. Ernest D. Farino created the Leemoid through stop motion animation. Filming took place in and around Baltimore, Maryland, from October 1976 to April 1977.

Release 🔗

The film was released on DVD by Retromedia Entertainment on February 26, 2002. Image Entertainment released it on November 15, 2005, as part of the Don Dohler Collection. Mill Creek Entertainment released it on July 19, 2011.

Reception 🔗

The film received generally negative reviews. TV Guide gave it two out of five stars, calling it “silly.” Dave Sindelar criticized the acting and direction. Critical Outcast acknowledged the film’s flaws but admired Dohler’s initiative. VideoHound’s Golden Movie Retriever awarded it one and a half out of four bones, noting the decent special effects.

Sequels 🔗

The Alien Factor 2: Alien Rampage was not a direct sequel. Fred Olen Ray, the Retromedia distributor, used the sequel-sounding title for marketing purposes. The original title was Alien Rampage, filmed in 1999 as Don Dohler’s comeback movie after an 11-year hiatus.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Alien_Factor

item.title: Alien Agent (2007 Film)
item.description:
Alien Agent (2007 Film) 🔗

This entry details the 2007 Canadian science fiction action film Alien Agent. It includes information about the film’s director, writers, producers, cast, release date, running time, budget, and other relevant details.

Plot 🔗

Rykker, an intergalactic warrior, is stranded on Earth and battles the Syndicate, a group of aliens plotting to take over the planet. Saylon, a Syndicate leader, arrives on Earth to build a wormhole for a full-scale invasion. Isis, the Syndicate’s leader, aims to destroy Rykker. Julie, whose family was killed by the Syndicate, seeks revenge and joins Rykker. They journey across the country, pursued by Isis and her forces. The climax occurs at a nuclear reactor, where Rykker and Julie fight Isis, Saylon, and their army to destroy the portal and prevent the invasion.

Cast 🔗

The film stars Mark Dacascos as Rykker, Amelia Cooke as Isis, and Emma Lahana as Julie. Other cast members include William MacDonald as Sheriff Devlin, Kim Coates as Carl Roderick, Billy Zane as Tom Hanson/Saylon, Dominiquie Vandenberg as Sartek, and Darren Shahlavi as Kaylor.

Reception 🔗

The film received negative reviews from critics. Adam-Troy Castro of Sci Fi Weekly criticized the film’s uninteresting characters and plot. Leah Holmes of SFX magazine gave it a low rating, calling it “stupid and nonsensical.” George Tiller of PopMatters also gave it a very poor rating.

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article, including reviews from Sci Fi Weekly, SFX magazine, and PopMatters.

External links 🔗

Links to the film’s entry on IMDb and the TCM Movie Database are provided.

Films directed by Jesse V. Johnson 🔗

A template listing other films directed by Jesse V. Johnson is included. Films listed include Pit Fighter (2005), Charlie Valentine (2009), Green Street Hooligans 2 (2009), The Butcher (2009), The Package (2013), Savage Dog (2017), Accident Man (2018), Triple Threat (2019), The Mercenary (2019), Avengement (2019), White Elephant (2022), One Ranger (2023), and Chief of Station (2024).

item.title: Communication with extraterrestrial intelligence
item.description:
Communication with Extraterrestrial Intelligence (CETI) 🔗

CETI is a branch of SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) that focuses on composing and deciphering interstellar messages that could theoretically be understood by another technological civilization. A well-known CETI experiment is the 1974 Arecibo message composed by Frank Drake. The abbreviations CETI and SETI are generic and do not refer to any particular organization like the SETI Institute. CETI research focuses on mathematical languages, pictorial systems (like the Arecibo message), algorithmic communication systems (ACETI), and computational approaches to detecting and deciphering “natural” language communication. Research also addresses how to overcome problems of decipherment in interplanetary communication, similar to the challenges posed by undeciphered writing systems in human communication like Linear A. In 2015, scientists including Douglas Vakoch, David Grinspoon, Seth Shostak, and David Brin discussed active SETI and the potential risks of transmitting messages to extraterrestrials. A statement signed by many in the SETI community emphasized the need for a global discussion before sending any messages.

History 🔗

In the 19th century, speculation about inhabitants of other planets was common, with many believing intelligent beings lived on the Moon, Mars, and/or Venus. Before radio, proposals for signaling extraterrestrials included Carl Friedrich Gauss’s 1820 suggestion to draw a giant Pythagorean triangle on the Siberian tundra and Joseph Johann Littrow’s 1819 idea to use the Sahara as a “blackboard” with trenches filled with water and kerosene to create signals. Astronomers like Franz von Paula Gruithuisen also looked for signs of life, claiming to see cities and agriculture on the Moon and evidence of life on Venus. By the late 1800s, Mars became the focus after Giovanni Schiaparelli reported “canali” (channels) on Mars, which were mistranslated as “canals,” sparking enthusiasm about Martian life. Inventor Charles Cros sought funding for a giant mirror to signal Martians, while Nikola Tesla believed his inventions could be used for interplanetary communication and claimed to have observed extraterrestrial radio signals. The Guzman Prize was created, offering 100,000 francs to the first person to establish interplanetary communication, excluding Mars.

Mathematical and Scientific Languages 🔗

This section covers artificial languages designed for interstellar communication.

Lincos (Lingua cosmica) 🔗

Hans Freudenthal’s Lincos: Design of a Language for Cosmic Intercourse (1960) expands upon Astraglossa to create a general-purpose language derived from basic mathematics and logic symbols. A dictionary resembling Lincos was featured in Carl Sagan’s novel Contact and its film adaptation.

Astraglossa 🔗

Lancelot Hogben’s 1963 essay “Astraglossa” describes a system for combining numbers and operators in a series of short and long pulses, where short pulses represent numbers and trains of long pulses represent symbols for addition, subtraction, etc.

Carl Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan’s 1985 science fiction novel Contact explores how a message might be constructed for communication with an alien civilization, using prime numbers as a starting point, followed by universal principles and facts of mathematics and science. Sagan also edited a nonfiction book on the subject, and an updated collection of articles was published in 2011.

A Language Based on the Fundamental Facts of Science 🔗

Carl Devito and Richard Oehrle’s 1992 paper, A language based on the fundamental facts of science, describes a language similar in syntax to Astraglossa and Lincos, but which builds its vocabulary around known physical properties.

Busch General-Purpose Binary Language Used in Lone Signal Transmissions 🔗

In 2010, Michael W. Busch created a general-purpose binary language later used in the Lone Signal project to transmit crowdsourced messages to extraterrestrial intelligence (METI). This was followed by an attempt to extend the syntax used in the Lone Signal hailing message to communicate in a way that, while neither mathematical nor strictly logical, was nonetheless understandable given the prior definition of terms and concepts in the Lone Signal hailing message. The Lone Signal project sent messages to Gliese 526 (HD 119850) in the constellation Boötes, with the message sent on July 10, 2013, and expected to arrive in 2031.

Pictorial Messages 🔗

Pictorial communication systems describe fundamental mathematical or physical concepts via simplified diagrams sent as bitmaps. These messages assume the recipient has similar visual capabilities and can understand basic mathematics and geometry. A critique is that they presume a shared understanding of shapes, which may not be the case with a species with substantially different vision.

Pioneer Probes 🔗

Two etched plaques, known as the Pioneer plaques, were included aboard the Pioneer 10 and Pioneer 11 spacecraft when they launched in 1972 and 1973. The plaques depict the location of the Solar System within the galaxy and the Earth within the Solar System, as well as the form of the human body.

Voyager Probes 🔗

Launched in 1977, the Voyager probes carried two golden records that were inscribed with diagrams similar to the Pioneer plaques, depicting the human form, the Solar System, and its location. Also included were recordings of images and sounds from Earth.

Arecibo Message 🔗

The Arecibo message, transmitted in 1974, was a 1,679-pixel bitmap that, when properly arranged into 73 rows and 23 columns, shows the numbers one through ten; the atomic numbers of hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and phosphorus; the formulas for the sugars and bases that make up the nucleotides of DNA; the number of nucleotides in the human genome; the double helix structure of DNA; a simple illustration of a human being and its height; the human population of Earth; a diagram of the Solar System; and an illustration of the Arecibo telescope with its diameter.

Cosmic Call Messages 🔗

The Cosmic Call messages consisted of digital sections – “Rosetta Stone”, a copy of the Arecibo Message, the Bilingual Image Glossary, and the Braastad message – as well as text, audio, video, and other image files submitted for transmission by people around the world. The “Rosetta Stone” was composed by Stéphane Dumas and Yvan Dutil, and represents a multi-page bitmap that builds a vocabulary of symbols representing numbers and mathematical operations. These messages were transmitted in 1999 and 2003 from Evpatoria Planetary Radar in Russia under the scientific guidance of Alexander L. Zaitsev. Richard Braastad coordinated the overall project. Star systems to which the messages were sent include 16 Cyg A, 15 Sge, HD 178428, Gl 777, Hip 4872, HD 245409, 55 Cnc, HD 10307, and 47 UMa.

Multi-Modal Messages 🔗

Teen-Age Message 🔗

The Teen-Age Message, composed by Russian scientists (Zaitsev, Gindilis, Pshenichner, Filippova) and teens, was transmitted from the 70-m dish of Evpatoria Deep Space Center in Ukraine to six star systems resembling that of the Sun on August 29 and September 3 and 4, 2001. The message consists of three parts: a coherent-sounding radio signal with slow Doppler wavelength tuning, analog information representing musical melodies performed on the theremin, and Arecibo-like binary digital information. Star systems to which the message was sent are HD 197076, 47 UMa, 37 Gem, HD 126053, HD 76151, and HD 193664.

Cosmic Call 2 (Cosmic Call 2003) Message 🔗

The Cosmic Call-2 message contained text, images, video, music, the Dutil/Dumas message, a copy of the 1974 Arecibo message, BIG = Bilingual Image Glossary, the AI program Ella, and the Braastad message.

Algorithmic Messages 🔗

Algorithmic communication systems describe a small set of mathematic and logic symbols that form the basis for a rudimentary programming language that the recipient can run on a virtual machine. Advantages include localized communication, forward error correction, and the ability to embed proxy agents within the message.

CosmicOS 🔗

CosmicOS, designed by Paul Fitzpatrick at MIT, describes a virtual machine that is derived from lambda calculus.

Logic Gate Matrices 🔗

Logic Gate Matrices (LGM), developed by Brian McConnell, describes a universal virtual machine that is constructed by connecting coordinates in an n-dimensional space via mathematics and logic operations.

Natural Language Messages 🔗

This research focuses on receiving a signal or message that is either not directed at us (eavesdropping) or one that is in its natural communicative form. Methods are being developed to detect if a signal has structure indicative of an intelligent source, categorize the type of structure detected, and then decipher its content. This structure modeling focuses on the search for generic human and inter-species language universals to devise computational methods by which language may be discriminated from non-language, and core structural syntactic elements of unknown languages may be detected. The challenges of deciphering undeciphered writing systems in human communication, such as Linear A, are relevant to the problems of interplanetary communication. In 2015, scientists discussed active SETI and the potential risks of transmitting messages to extraterrestrials, leading to a statement advocating for a global discussion before any messages are sent.

In the 19th century, speculation about inhabitants of other planets was common, with many believing in intelligent beings on the Moon, Mars, and Venus. Before radio, proposals for signaling extraterrestrials included Carl Friedrich Gauss’s idea of drawing a giant Pythagorean triangle on the Siberian tundra and Joseph Johann Littrow’s suggestion to use the Sahara as a “blackboard” with trenches filled with kerosene for burning signals. Astronomers like Franz von Paula Gruithuisen looked for signs of life on the Moon and Venus, though his claims were later refuted. Interest shifted to Mars after Giovanni Schiaparelli’s discovery of “canali” (mistranslated as “canals”), sparking enthusiasm about Martian life, which eventually proved illusory. The Guzman Prize was established to reward the first person to establish interplanetary communication, excluding Mars.

Mathematical and Scientific Languages 🔗

This section details attempts to create languages that could be universally understood based on mathematics and logic.

Lincos (Lingua cosmica) 🔗

Carl Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan’s 1985 science fiction novel Contact explores how a message might be constructed for communication with an alien civilization, using prime numbers, mathematics, and science. Sagan also edited a nonfiction book on the subject.

A Language Based on the Fundamental Facts of Science 🔗

Carl Devito and Richard Oehrle’s 1992 paper describes a language similar to Astraglossa and Lincos, but builds its vocabulary around known physical properties.

Busch General-Purpose Binary Language Used in Lone Signal Transmissions 🔗

In 2010, Michael W. Busch created a general-purpose binary language used in the Lone Signal project to transmit crowdsourced messages to extraterrestrial intelligence. The Lone Signal project transmitted messages to Gliese 526 in the constellation Boötes.

The Arecibo message, transmitted in 1974, was a 1,679-pixel bitmap showing the numbers one through ten, atomic numbers of key elements, formulas for DNA nucleotides, the number of nucleotides in the human genome, the DNA double helix, a human figure and height, the human population, a diagram of the Solar System, and an illustration of the Arecibo telescope.

Star systems targeted included 16 Cyg A, 15 Sge, HD 178428, Gl 777, Hip 4872, HD 245409, 55 Cnc, HD 10307, and 47 UMa.

This section discusses messages that combine different forms of communication, such as sound, images, and text.

The Teen-Age Message, composed by Russian scientists (Zaitsev, Gindilis, Pshenichner, Filippova) and teens, was transmitted from the 70-m dish of Evpatoria Deep Space Center in Ukraine to six star systems resembling the Sun on August 29 and September 3 and 4, 2001. The message consisted of a coherent-sounding radio signal, musical melodies performed on the theremin, and Arecibo-like binary digital information. Star systems targeted included 197076, 47 UMa, 37 Gem, 126053, 76151, and 193664.

The Cosmic Call-2 message contained text, images, video, music, the Dutil/Dumas message, a copy of the 1974 Arecibo message, BIG = Bilingual Image Glossary, the AI program Ella, and the Braastad message.

Logic Gate Matrices (LGM), developed by Brian McConnell, describes a universal virtual machine constructed by connecting coordinates in an n-dimensional space via mathematics and logic operations.

Natural Language Messages 🔗

This research focuses on detecting and deciphering signals or messages that are either not directed at us (eavesdropping) or are in their natural communicative form. Methods are being developed to detect if a signal has structure indicative of an intelligent source, categorize the type of structure detected, and then decipher its content. This structure modeling focuses on the search for generic human and inter-species language universals to devise computational methods by which language may be discriminated from non-language, and core structural syntactic elements of unknown languages may be detected. John Elliott is a key researcher in this area. A key concept is that human languages conform to a Zipfian distribution, which may also apply to alien languages. Laurance Doyle explains that the slope of a line that represents individual tokens in a stream of tokens may indicate whether the stream contains linguistic or other structured content.

CETI Researchers 🔗

This section lists key individuals involved in CETI research:

  • Frank Drake (SETI Institute): SETI pioneer, composed the Arecibo message.
  • Dr John Elliott: Researches strategies for deciphering ’natural’ language messages, focusing on algorithms to detect intelligent-like structure.
  • Laurence Doyle (SETI Institute): Studies animal communication and develops statistical measures of complexity in animal utterances.
  • Stephane Dumas: Developed Cosmic Call messages and techniques for generating noise-resistant 2-D symbols.
  • Yvan Dutil: Developed Cosmic Call messages with Stephane Dumas.
  • Paul Fitzpatrick (MIT): Developed CosmicOS system based on lambda calculus.
  • Brian McConnell: Developed a framework for algorithmic communication systems (ACETI).
  • Marvin Minsky (MIT AI researcher): Believed aliens may think similarly to humans, permitting communication, and proposed including algorithms in interstellar messages.
  • Carl Sagan: Co-authored the Arecibo message and was heavily involved in SETI.
  • Douglas Vakoch (METI): Editor of Archaeology, Anthropology, and Interstellar Communication.

item.title: Alien Terminator (1988 film)
item.description:
Alien Terminator (1988 film) 🔗

This article details the 1988 Italian film Alien Terminator, also known as Top Line. It distinguishes it from the 1995 film of the same name.

Top Line 🔗

This section provides the original Italian title of the film, which is Top Line.

Film Details 🔗

This section presents key information about the film in a table format:

  • Director: Nello Rossati (also credited as Ted Archer)
  • Writers: Roberto Gianviti and Nello Rossati
  • Stars: Franco Nero and George Kennedy
  • Cinematography: Mario DiLeo
  • Editor: Adalberto Ceccarelli
  • Music: Maurizio Dami
  • Release Date: 1988
  • Country: Italy
  • Language: Italian

Plot 🔗

The plot revolves around Ted Angelo, an alcoholic writer who discovers a 16th-century Spanish ship inside a mountain cave in Cartagena, Colombia. He learns the cave is actually the inside of a crashed UFO. He is pursued by hitmen, a Nazi fugitive named Heinrich Holzmann, and CIA operatives. He teams up with art historian June and eventually involves his ex-wife Maureen. Maureen is revealed to be an alien who has been disguising herself as a human and manipulating world events. She is killed by June. Ted and June go into hiding with an indigenous tribe, where Ted continues to write about his experiences.

Cast 🔗

This section lists the main actors and their respective roles in the film:

  • Franco Nero as Ted Angelo
  • George Kennedy as Heinrich Holzmann
  • Deborah Moore (credited as Deborah Barrymore) as June
  • Mary Stavin as Maureen De Havilland
  • William Berger as Alonso Kintero
  • Shirley Hernandez as Juanita
  • Larry Dolgin
  • Robert Redcross

Release 🔗

This section details the film’s release information. It was released theatrically in Germany on September 22, 1988. It was released on Region 1 DVD on May 25, 2004. It is also available for streaming on platforms like Amazon.

Reception 🔗

This section summarizes critical reception of the film. Sci-Fi 100 noted the initial lack of science fiction elements but found the last 30 minutes more engaging. Film Authority described the film as a mix of Romancing the Stone, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and The Terminator.

See also 🔗

This section lists a related film:

  • Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)
  • List of Italian films of 1988

References 🔗

This section provides a list of citations used in the article, including books, websites, and databases.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to the film’s IMDb page.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Terminator_(1988_film)

item.title: List of UFO-related hoaxes
item.description:
List of UFO-related Hoaxes 🔗

This article provides a compilation of various hoaxes related to unidentified flying objects (UFOs). It categorizes these hoaxes into different types, including airship hoaxes, crashed UFO hoaxes, sighting hoaxes, and photographic hoaxes.

Airship Hoaxes 🔗

This section details several instances of airship hoaxes, primarily from the late 19th century. Key events include:

  • April Fool’s Day 1897, Omaha, Nebraska: Two practical jokers launched a helium balloon with a burning wicker basket.
  • April 17, 1897, Dallas, Texas: Three boys created a “mystery airship” sighting using a kerosene-soaked cotton ball attached to a turkey vulture.
  • April 19, 1897, Leroy, Kansas: Alexander Hamilton reported an airship lassoing a heifer, which was later published in the Yates Center Farmer’s Advocate.
  • 1909 Airship Sighting Wave: Wallace Tillinghast claimed to have built and flown an airship extensively over the Northeastern United States.

Crashed UFO Hoaxes 🔗

This section focuses on hoaxes involving purported crashed UFOs.

  • 1884, Dundy County, Nebraska: The Nebraska State Journal published two hoax articles about a crashed UFO.

Alien Autopsy 🔗

This subsection details the Ray Santilli “Alien Autopsy” film hoax.

  • 1993: Ray Santilli presented film footage allegedly showing an autopsy of an alien from the Roswell UFO incident in 1947.
  • 1995: The American Fox Broadcasting Company broadcast the footage in Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction.
  • The footage was later revealed to be a hoax involving latex dummies.
  • Santilli claimed he bought the film from Jack Barnett, who falsely claimed to be a commander in the US army.

1967 Flying Saucer Hoax in England 🔗

This section describes a hoax involving the placement of six ‘flying saucers’ in southern England.

  • September 1967: Apprentices from the Royal Aircraft Establishment at Farnborough placed six ‘flying saucers’ between the Thames Estuary and the Bristol Channel.
  • The hoax was part of Rag Week and intended to raise money for charity.

British Roswell 🔗

This section discusses a “miniature UFO” discovered in Sipho Moor near Scarborough, North Yorkshire.

  • 1957: A small piece of metal with hieroglyphs was found.
  • Experts deemed it most likely a hoax.

Sighting Hoaxes 🔗

This section lists sighting hoaxes.

  • Maury Island Incident (1947)
  • Morristown UFO Hoax (2009)

Photographic Hoaxes 🔗

This section focuses on photographic hoaxes related to UFOs.

Photograph of “an alien” taken at Ilkley Moor (1987) 🔗

This subsection details a photograph alleged to be of an alien taken in West Yorkshire.

  • December 1, 1987: A photograph taken on Ilkley Moor was claimed to depict an alien.
  • The Daily Star claimed to expose it as a hoax in 1989, identifying the “alien” as an insurance broker.
  • Belgian investigators questioned how experienced investigators could have been misled by such a hoax.

See also 🔗

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles.

  • List of hoaxes
  • Photograph of Petit-Rechain

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_UFO-related_hoaxes

item.title: Alien implants
item.description:
Alien Implants 🔗

Alien implants are physical objects that some people believe are placed in their bodies after being abducted by aliens. These implants are purported to have various capabilities, including telepresence, mind control, and biotelemetry.

History 🔗

The concept of alien implants can be traced back to a 1957 radio show interview with ufologist John Robinson, who recounted a neighbor’s claim of being kidnapped by aliens and controlled by “small earphones.” Betty Andreasson claimed aliens implanted a device in her nose in 1967. Dorothy Wallis made a similar claim in 1983. Authors like Whitley Strieber popularized the idea of alien abductions and associated implants. John E. Mack examined an object given to him by a client who claimed it came out of her nose after an abduction. Roger Leir claimed to have removed alien implants from patients. Skeptic Joe Nickell suggests that supposed alien implants are ordinary materials that become lodged in the body and surrounded by scar tissue. Virgil Priscu stated that there is “No mystery, no implants”.

Popular Culture 🔗

Alien implants, depicted as small needles inserted into victims, first appeared in the 1953 film Invaders from Mars.

See Also 🔗

The article references “matchbox sign”, a similar phenomenon related to delusional parasitosis.

References 🔗

The article cites several sources, including:

  • Peter Rogerson’s article “Fairyland’s Hunters, Part One” in Magonia magazine.
  • Joe Nickell’s book Real-Life X-Files: Investigating the Paranormal.
  • Susan A. Clancy’s book Abducted: How People Come To Believe They Were Kidnapped By Aliens.

External Links 🔗

The article provides links to:

  • “Scientific Analysis of an ‘Alien Implant’” by Susan Blackmore.
  • “Skeptoid #519: Alien Implants” by Brian Dunning.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_implants

item.title: Crop Circles
item.description:
Crop Circles 🔗

Crop circles are patterns created by flattening a crop. This is the primary meaning of the term.

Crop Circles (Other Uses) 🔗

This section lists other uses of the term “Crop Circles,” primarily referring to musical works. Dean Brody has an album titled Crop Circles released in 2013. Jon Bellion has a song called “Crop Circles” released in 2019. Tash Sultana has a song called “Crop Circles” from the 2021 album Terra Firma.

Other Uses 🔗

This section lists a documentary film titled Crop Circles: Quest for Truth directed by William Gazecki in 2002.

See Also 🔗

This section directs the reader to another album with a similar title: Crop Circle by Nines, released in 2018.

This page serves as a disambiguation page, listing articles associated with the title “Crop Circles.” It instructs users who arrived via an internal link to correct the link to point to the intended article.
